158806168.review:
I bought a game in early access that had a roadmap and promises for content.  That game was never delivered and now I have to purchase another DLC just to get the game I was originally promised.  

"Exclusive to Prometheus" is the norm for new updates. The literal definition of bait and switch.

The game might get better, but I can't fundamentally support devs who rug pulled a community that supported them in early access. 

If you don't give a shit about that then the game might be for you. 

It's a bog standard survival crafting game with decent graphics and a grindy resource economy.  It takes too long to get to the stone building tier and the lighting storms can and will set your wood base on fire. You will lose everything you worked for and have to grind it again.  This is intended gameplay.  If you skip the open world and just do missions, it gets incredibly boring with half a dozen enemies set on repeat.  

Give it another year to bake.  It's technically out of EA, but still for all intents and purposes still in EA. You'll likely have to buy a 3rd DLC by the time the game is in a state the devs promised when it first launched.

160795971.review:
I really want to like this game, it does a bunch of things well, but keeps dropping the ball on important things.

Icarus advertises itself as a hardcore survival crafting experience, but it fails to deliver on that promise.  Instead it provides a really high quality "rustic dollhouse experience with annoying yet unavoidable combat".

Let's start with that they do well:

Base building:  You can make your dream cabin.  The building system takes a lot of resources, and it makes every placement seem important.  You have to maintain your buildings in the face of storms, and there's a rudimentary structural support system that means you have to think about your decisions, and not just place improbable floating mansions.  Everything is a little dark inside since the lighting system isn't fully baked, but honestly that's my only complaint.  I enjoy building things in Icarus.

Exploration:  They did a rally good job crafting a beautiful world to explore.  There's hidden caves that you need to track down in order to get the resources you need for building, and the caves feel creepy and claustrophobic.  In general, the darkness, at night and in caves feels dangerous, and that is appreciated.  I enjoy exploration in Icarus.

Then there' the systems they want to work well, but don't:

Combat:  I think they want the world to feel hostile, but it doesn't, it just feels annoying.  You either need to kill things that offer no challenge (e.g. deer, rabbits, birds) in a way that feels too easy and kind of gross, or you need to kill annoying bullet sponges that run after you full speed while you stab them in the face.  Or jump on a rock and stab them in the face.  Or jump over a stream and shoot arrows in their face.  The most interesting enemies are shielded everywhere except their face, which means you have to run backwards for longer, because you need to take more shots to get more face hits.  Sometimes there are a lot of things at once that you have to stab/shoot in the face, so you have to run backwards for a while to herd them into  a group while shooting them in the face.

Combat in Icarus is a nuisance, and I think the developers realize that, because they've recently released a game mode that requires less of it, but I wish they would just fix it.  If you made the creatures and the player less spongy, and turned it into something that more closely resembles danger in the wild, it would be more fun, and fit the game's theme better.  

Sessions:  The idea behind Icarus is that you can avoid the boredom of tech-tree-climbing that's endemic to all games in the genre by time-limiting the sessions.  The idea is that you will land, quickly set up the bare minimum to accomplish the mission, go do the mission, and return to space.  Unfortunately since construction is so resource intensive, this means that every mission begins with a lot of boring labor, to build a structure you probably like, only to throw it away at the end of the mission, the majority of which are not particularly enjoyable (1:place macguffin. 2:level-appropriate animals attack. 3: annoying combat to defend the macguffin.  4: rinse, repeat). 

The idea here is great, but it runs into a wall as a consequence of poor execution.  As it stands, the missions are more boring than the tech-tree climb, so I just kind of ignore them because they use up resources that I could otherwise be dedicating to my dream cabin.  I genuinely wish there were some cool settler-related missions, but that would require NPCs and AI, which is not where this game shines.

One of the most frustrating thing about Icarus is how it takes a very interesting premise, and makes it boring. "Be part of colonizing/exploiting a very hostile planet with exotic materials, by running backwards and repeatedly stabbing earth animals in the face while a beeping thing beeps."  I honestly dream about some "State of Decay 2" style mechanics being introduced to this game, which would give it stakes, but the developers seem to habitually avoid AI spending time on AI.

To be honest, I think the primary failing of the game comes down to AI.  Game AI is hard, but if you don't do it the game is boring or annoying.  Until they add some meaningful character interactions to the game, I'm going to avoid it.

161048381.review:
I tried giving this game a fair shot. Being someone who loves the survival genre, playing everything from the go-to Valheim to the more obscure The Long Dark, I'm fairly versed in the nature of survival games and what makes one good or not. 

One key aspect that Icarus does very poorly is leveling. When a title such as Valheim gives you the pure freedom to unlock or "learn" new items simply by finding an item (e.g Copper unlocking Bronze items), it painfully obvious how bad Icarus's system is when tied directly to XP points. You want to progress to Steal, well your stuck to hitting an xp level to manually chose to unlock the option to use Steal items. I understand this is a design choice, but from my point of view only incentives cheesing the game to hitting an xp wall, aka just murdering animals to boost xp. It's a very poorly done system in my opinion.

Another major downside is my opinion is the point of doing any of this. You might finally hit an XP level that gives you the ability to use Iron tools for instance, but after building these items your left questioning, why do I need any of this to begin with?!?!? Is it only to hit the next item in the tier, sooooo this leads to back to the original XP grind of doing things literally just to hit a "level". In short, it does not feel rewarding or dynamic, but instead feels very restrictive. 

Lastly, is animal system. It's down right terrible. You want to take a trek into the snow biome and look for new items, good luck fighting a million wolves, bears, etc in route. It's comical the level this is taken too. I've broken 3 weapons in one trip killing 100+ wolves or other enemies in a small few hundred meter distance traveled. Watching enemies literally spawn directly in front you, after having murdered hundreds to that point feels downright stupid. It literally feels like an artificial difficulty metric that is used to slow progression just for the sake of doing so. Never does it feel ground in reality. 

I say all this to bring me to my last point and why I uninstalled the game. You work all these broken systems to go out for a long trek to explore and find "cool" new places, only to face broken gameplay after broken gameplay. Break every weapon you have on one outing because the game throws a stupid around of enemies at you or you enter a cave which you later find have no way out and your character and all it's gear is essentially stuck because the terrain navigation doesn't allow you to exit the cave. All in all, it feels like a pointless grind, leaving you to question if you've indeed wasted hours of you time into a broken mess. Sadly, you'll come to realize this is exactly what you signed up for and I just couldn't bear to grind my teeth over it anymore.

Recommendation = Avoid and push down any questions of "this game looks beautiful, I wonder if it's good?". It's not and you will leave disappointed.

160993787.review:
Let's start with how this game was developed.

Apparently a bunch of content that was promised in Early Access is now sold as DLC. I didn't realise this when I bought the game, but I also bought it on sale. So for now this hasn't really affected me much, but if you are worried about what the devs might do in future, here is something to know.
 
Having said that, the game is being actively developed, new things are added all the time, and perhaps having funding through DLCs is helping this aspect.

The premise: terraforming gone wrong, you get sent down to do things for various factions. But why on Earth (excuse the pun), would you be sent to a new planet with not even a bedroll? I understand that you can earn some currency that allows you to go down with some equipment. But we can build rockets and space stations. You should be able to get basic supplies with you. I am pretty sure that's what NASA plans to do with Mars. Also let me make my bedroll out of fibre or something. I don't need all that leather.

So you kind of have to go, "Okay so the premise is kind of cool, but there are contradictions. We can terraform planets, we can build rockets, and space stations, but we must be in an hyper-capitalist world, where you have to earn ABSOLUTELY everything yourself, even a bedroll. And someone must have gone cheap on the suits, because we can get pneumonia. In caves. Only." And even though the thought was amusing for a short 2 seconds, it still didn't make much sense. So I just shrugged and moved on.

I found the beginning of the game on your first character is very grindy. So grindy that I wound up modding some of that. I still want a challenge, but I feel that maybe having some sliders like Valheim and V-Rising might do this game some good. The game takes off at around level 20ish. But it takes a long time to get there. 

This game has some decent mods though, and the fact that it is moddable is certainly a plus. I think most people mod survival games at some point.

The crafting progression in this is rather good. It is what is keeping me engaged. I really like how No Man's Sky lets you automate certain things and how you can create extractors, how you can power bases, etc. And this game does the same thing. It has several tiers of things to craft, etc. It isn't something new, but its implementation is just satisfying.

I rather like the weather events too. They add jeopardy. You do learn easy tricks to trivialise them, but a thunderstorm can set the forest on fire. And that you have to deal with. I managed to set a forest on fire by being on fire myself and running towards a lake. So... I burned all bushes between my cabin and the lake. Yeah. I do like how environment hazards work here. I would have rolled on clear ground. But you can't do that here. 

Or you are exploring somewhere, wind up in a snowy mountain range, a hail storm hits, you hide under a rock but four wolves and one snow leopard come to greet you, so you can't stay put into your rocky shelter anymore. I think the weather is a strong selling point for sure.

The game looks pretty good in general.

The combat is a bit of a downer, and it's rather binary. You hit the face with a ranged weapon, you kill stuff really quick (and can often one shot). If you do not, you have to strafe in a circle with a knife and spam your left click until the thing is dead. That's it. No reason to craft any other weapon other than your ranged weapon of choice and a knife. You might like to build something in case what you are trying to hunt is a bit too hard, so it can't reach you straight away. And then you try to hit it in the face. It's almost like you are playing Fortnite but this is not as smooth.

Animations in third person are not very good. And the aiming is a bit wonky. All the game does is to zoom out a little when you are in third person, but when you hit something, you are still trying to hit things with the dot in the middle of your screen, which is slightly removed from your character. You are not actually trying to make contact with your character. So I just stay in first person, as third person seems to be an after-thought. I wonder if it was added some time in Early Access as a player request, but it was never well implemented.

Icarus has an open world and a mission system. (It also has outposts, which basically is a non-aggressive version of the game where you mostly just build.) The mission system works like a rogue-lite game. You do the missions, extract, lose anything you might have built on the surface. But you earn currency to unlock new equipment and your character still levels and earns talent points. Yet, not all missions involve creating bases. Some are just hunting. Some are just gathering ores. You get the gist. It actually does not feel like you are wasting your time (at least I don't). I like having missions to do. It's almost like Deep Rock Galactic in that respect.

But if you like to build persistent bases, you go in the open world, and then eventually craft the mission board, and then you can do most missions in the open world too. That makes it so you can access the equipment from both progression systems - the equipment you get with currency, and the equipment you get via levelling tech trees.

The game also has talent trees, which is something I really like. You can become a better hunter, a better builder, a better forager, etc.

CONCLUSION
Once you get past the initial logic issues with the premise, and if combat isn't a make or break proposition for you, this is a very good survival game.

I have put many hours int othis game with solo play and co-op. I have completed all 60 levels and I am working on a second character for specialization.  I have put far less hours into other games so that should say something positive about Icarus to everyone.  YET, there are lots of fixes needed for this game.  

BUILD - It is not easy to build as the snapping tool is basic and difficult to work with.Build areas from ground to sky need addressing as you may not be able to stack or build over a space to achieve your plan.  I ahve played other survival games where this has been address successfully.

There is nothing more annoying than trying to put a ladder on what you have built only to have to undo and redo a number of times to only get close. This pertains from the build point ground to structure.  You can easly put a ladder on top of a build, but it will not snap to your target.

ENEMIES! - Basic enemies are easly dealt with until you get into the Arctic.  Basic enemies become crazy hard to kill. For example, a brown forest bear is powerful but can be killed in 4-6 well placed shots to the face.  A polar bear however may take 14 - 20 arrows to the face.  You can succeed, but will more than likely be killed.  Then add being attacked by more than one at a time.  Rediculous.  

CLIPPING - This game has some horrible clipping in it.  Enemies can swipe through barracades  without destroying them and kill you.  Make sure you have plenty of room away from walls to survive.  Needler enemy can shoot needles through rock and hit you. It would be okay if it were not so rediculously difficult to kill them without advanced weaponry.

INSTRUCTIONS - There are NONE.  You must rely on the community to answer questions.  There is no manual for this game that I know of.  Look for Wiki's to answer your questions and join the community chat.

161630556.review:
Icarus, the survival game I scoped out since release but never purchased. I held off on this one at first due to lukewarm reviews and later due to the cost of the experience (if you include Styx and Prometheus in that equation).

That said, I'm glad I did finally pick this game up and I would recommend it to fans of the genre, but in particular people, like me, who really enjoy the early portion of survival games. The mission-based part of the game (the original part that many people did not like) is basically repeatedly starting over with nothing (a bit of a rogue like experience) and as you progress you do get to bring more things down with you that you purchase with meta currency that you are earning on each mission. This gives purpose to constantly restarting and the missions also give finite objectives for each "game".

I've enjoyed the mission bit enough that I haven't even started the other types of games (which you can run concurrently) including open world (more like a classic survival experience with some of the elements from the mission based game mode), and outpost (like a peaceful building option). The same character can run all 3 types of games at once from what I gather which is neat. You don't bring things between the modes but you keep your talents and research unlocks.

Basically, TLDR, I think this one is a must buy if you like the start of survival games especially and if you like the idea of a rogue-like survival game :) It does everything else pretty well and the storms definitely make survival more interesting, but I'd say the biggest difference is the sort of meta game of missions and unlocks. They also seem to be really active (weekly?) in content updates.

161578861.review:
Icarus is one of the most well put together survival games that are on steam to this day. Let me tell you some good, and some bad things about this game. Now, I have had Icarus since game preview launch, and have survived around 300 hrs on my most recent save. 
  I give this game a high rating due to it's constant fixes to the problems the community makes the devs aware of. if you start playing the game new now compared to when they launched it, you wouldn't understand 100% how far they have come with Icarus. 
 When you first start, the game is a bit rough and it's slightly difficult to survive things like lightning storms, and other bad weather due to the physics. The weather aspect in this game is above and beyond with detail. Buildings can take damage from more severe weather, even heavy wind depending on the materiel used for building. Along with the weather aspects of reality, they have given you the gift of parasites, bacteria, hypothermia, overheating, dehydration, and a few other things that may be a challenge throughout your play through.
Lets get into the building tho cause that is a top interest in this game for sure. Building has come a long way and Icarus has it down to a science. Straight to the point with how to build walls, floor, doors and ceilings, and other basic building blocks such as foundations and stairs. the use of a construction hammer makes it so you can change materiel of said building pieces without removing them, which makes re organizing a lot easier. With a wide variety of materials to use for building as well as crafting, the game offers you a more laid back style of building and crafting. Physics in building is what makes it so much more than just putting floors down and walls. support is Needed for building in this game or it will fall, and it will collapse. between the weather, and the detail in lighting, building gives you a place to come back to from your hunting/gathering missions. It gives you that sense of excitement to come back from an hr long grind of gathering resources to build yourself up to those next items you need, instead of coming back to just a boring 4x4 house with a roof. 
  Along with the great building perspective i do have to say there are a few things that make it not so great sometimes, but they are working on everything that the community throws at them. Every now and then you'll experience a couple display glitches like weapons not getting pulled out in your hands when you select them in your hot bar. Clay and other resources that require a sledge hammer to break, a lot of the time pieces will fall into the ground and you cannot pick them up. when trying to repair a lantern in your inventory just as you can do with your tools and weapons, it will not repair the lantern. It will say it is repaired but as soon as you turn it on, the burn time falls back to zero time. 

If you are looking for a survival game that has not only Misions, Creative mode, And Outposts. This game is the game to get when it comes to a survival game with actual content to keep your mind busy. Highly recommend Starting with a Open World Save, and playing a long term save on each map. it makes losing all the progress you make on a mission not so bad to lose when you can load an open world (which has the ability to earn you just as much if not more credits/exotics along the way!!

159965695.review:
Icarus has come a long way from its rocky launch. There are now significantly more missions, game modes such as open world, and additional content through DLCs. The game mechanics have undergone drastic changes since its initial release, making it a strongly underrated game deserving way more recognition.

Initially, Icarus was a game where players were sent on missions with a timer that continued even when they were not in the game. However, it has evolved into a much richer experience with the introduction of features like an open world gamemode, dedicated servers, and a variety of animals and alien creatures. Players can engage in activities such as taming mounts, hunting, fishing, and intricate building mechanics, which have greatly enriched the gameplay experience.

Whether you're embarking on a solo mission, riding a buffalo into battle against wolves or lions, facing off against the giant worm boss, or peacefully constructing a cabin in the outpost game mode, Icarus offers a diverse range of experiences. 

One notable aspect of Icarus is its responsive development team, who are always attentive to player feedback. This makes a positive community atmosphere and contributes to ongoing improvements to the game.

I highly recommend purchasing Icarus and investing in its DLCs. If you enjoy building I would definitely recommend supporting the developers through purchasing in game maps like outposts or furniture packs as this is a great way to show appreciation for their hard work and dedication. Overall, I hope this review was helpful for people considering buying Icarus.

161195039.review:
I want to start by saying I absolutely love this game and I love the direction the devs are taking it down.

I bought this game around the week 70 update because a friend talked me into it, we fully exhausted all of the games content in about 40 hours time on a multiplayer server. We were really enjoying the game and knew it had a lot of potential. But ultimately we put the game down for a while to play our other go-to games. 

Fast forward a year later and the devs have been putting out WEEKLY updates for over 52 weeks... This is an unbelievable W for the dev team. What other game devs do you know of who never fail to crank out quality content and listen to their players?

A few days ago I remembered the existence of Icarus and the sweet bliss of being lost in the middle of a hurricane with only a knife made out of bone and burlap sack armor. Running until I'm out of breath from grizzly bears, swimming across a river just to catch a virus from the water and get pneumonia from being out in the cold rain all night. Many times I overstayed my welcome in the caves trying to get that last bit of precious ore just to catch pneumonia over 10km from our base of operations. Then I had to saddle a large bird species in order to make the trek back to base and find that lightning struck the wooden house and it burned down and destroyed our rooftop farming operation.

When I say this game is good, I mean it. This is hands down one of the best crafting survival sandbox games ever made, and the patch notes that I've missed for the last year gave me FOMO. Now I'm reinstalling the game so that I can host a server and my buddy and I can see who can catch the bigger fish, or see who get's mauled by a kamodo dragon first...

If you like survival crafting, perk trees and leveling, extraction shooters and spec ops missions, resource management, or just simply turning off your brain and charging at a wooly mammoth with a knife, this game will sink you deep and keep you going for many many hours.

Here's my take,

A (potentially) great game with very nice graphics and a fairly immersive environment. The tech tree is straight forward and level progression is simple and for the most part, intuitive. 

I'm not sure what to think about being able to cheese a game by bringing in an established character into a new world. it seems overpowered if a group wants to start fresh, or there's some new players in the game but one person decides not to start fresh.... I'm on the fence with this concept..but this is my opinion. Not sure if you can force the game to not allow characters from previous games on the server or not.

But... 

Holy Grind. 

I understand the concept of getting stone for a stone foundation... I'll never understand (in a game) where you need to get Iron Nails and wood as well. It's a stone foundation, I'd even be fine with the concept that it takes more stone to make the foundation sure as that makes sense. But, it seems VERY deliberate to make you grind resources purely for the sake of grinding resources.

For this reason, I can't honestly give this game great review.

Has all the tools to be a Monster good game. But making things complex for building, and mainly just the structure building, purely for the idea to be complex and grinding just takes away all the fun aspects of the game, which there are some really nice aspects to the game. 

If they simplify the game, I'll probably sink tons of hours into it. 

Till then, it will sit on the shelf.

105885045.review:
I wish Steam would let me give a mixed review for this game because my mind is really split down the middle on this one. I like so many more things about this game than I hate but the things that I hate, I REALLY hate. I would tentatively recommend this game for big-time lovers of survival games. For anyone else, I would maybe wait and check back in on the game status in a year or so. I feel frustrated because this game has enormous potential. It has all the right pieces and building blocks, they just aren’t quite fitting together the right way. Icarus has a lot going for itself but in its current state, the game leaves much to be desired. There’s a lot to talk about here so I’m gonna break it down with some pros and cons.

Pros:
The game is beautiful. Even without cranking the graphics up to their max, the game looks and feels breathtaking. Lighting and shadows are crisp and dynamic, the environment oscillates easily through a beautiful day/night cycle, and the general atmosphere and ambience is well-rounded.

The survival mechanics are fantastic. With the player needing to monitor things like body temperature, thirst, hunger, and oxygen levels, keeping yourself alive requires attentiveness but is not unnecessarily burdensome.

Forest fires! Finally, a survival game that lets you set a tree on fire and watch in morbid glee as an entire forest goes up in flames!

Inclement weather events! With random weather events from minor winds to severe blizzards, this adds a whole new survival aspect to the game. Some weather events are little more than an inconvenience whereas others can cause trees to topple over, make you the victim of a lightning strike, or tear the roof right off your house. While the weather events can be unforgiving and deadly, I must say this is perhaps my favorite aspect of the game.

Unique gameplay. This is the only survival game I’ve played that essentially has you start fresh with each new mission, dropping you into the map with nothing. While I do think this system is a new and interesting take on a survival game with good potential, I have some major criticisms about the way this is actually implemented.

Cons:
The chief issue that I have with the game is that the game flow is severely hindered by the incongruity between the mission lengths and the time investment of having to start from scratch for each mission. I’m actually quite a fan of the idea of having to regularly start fresh but the way this works in Icarus is pretty frustrating. Most missions take between 30 min and 6 hours to complete which just isn’t long enough for the grind of starting over to be anything other than criminally boring. I think this “start from scratch” idea could still work but only after significant edits to the gameplay workflow. There are many potential solutions to fix this tedious gameplay but I don’t have the space to suggest any here and still discuss the other major cons. Whatever the case, it feels like the missions are at an awkward stage of length: long enough to require you to invest time into gathering resources, crafting tools/weapons, and building stable shelters, but not long enough for you to really sink your teeth into the medium and high tiers of the craftable items which brings me to my next point:

Most medium and high-tier craftable items are effectively useless. A majority of these items require unnecessarily intensive resource gathering to yield an item that is only mildly more effective than its lower-tier counterpart. This problem is compounded by the fact that you cannot take any of your crafted items with you for the next mission so why bother wasting an hour of your time trying to make a weapon that is only marginally better than a simpler one that will still get the job done?

Plot/premise incongruities. I feel that in order for a mission-based survival game like this to be effective and engaging, it must rely on some sort of overarching premise to bind the different game elements together. The devs set themselves up beautifully for this in advertisements and the general game aesthetic but really just fail to follow through with it. I love the idea that Icarus was a lifeless planet that humans tried (and failed) to terraform into Earth.2.0. Unfortunately, I feel like the creators use this setting as a crutch to haphazardly excuse various game elements rather than investing themselves into creating an interesting reality and then using the game to reveal that reality to the player. E.G., It’s mentioned that the atmosphere of the planet turned “toxic” during the terraforming process which is why the planet is uninhabitable for humans. But if that’s the case, why are there still bears and wolves and deer walking around? I was initially expecting that the player would slowly discover that the toxic atmosphere had caused the plants/animals to evolve strange characteristics that allow them to survive the hostile environment, but by all counts, the deer on Icarus are no different than the deer that wander through my neighborhood in suburban Colorado. This is just one of many many examples of missed opportunities with the sci-fi elements of the game but at the end of the day, the pine trees in this foreign, extraterrestrial landscape are the same bland trees growing in my backyard. Bummer.

The polar bears… I do not know what the devs had goin on in their personal lives when they made the polar bears in this game but when you’re going up against 1300 pounds of pure hatred that can run at 92 miles per hour, scale near-vertical cliffs, and slap your shrimpy lil biped butt back into orbit, your best hope is to pray.

Just generally fighting hostile animals. It’s not that it’s particularly hard, it’s just wildly inconsistent. I think this inconsistency arises mostly because face shots deal significant bonus damage to animals (which makes sense); the problem is that the hitboxes are either terribly buggy or woefully oversimplified. You must hit an animal directly in the face (not head) to receive the damage bonus; hitting an animal in the side/back of the head or neck will do the same amount of damage as hitting it in the foot. The damage dealt to you by the animals is also terribly inconsistent. In some instances, hostile animals struggle to do any damage to you at all whereas other times, they can deal massive damage without even looking in your direction. They are also able to deal damage for about a full second after they are killed meaning it’s not uncommon to barely survive an encounter with a bear only to be killed moments later by the bear’s lifeless corpse (note that this has happened to me in both online multiplayer and offline solo so I don’t suspect this is a lag/ping issue).

Scientific blasphemy. Maybe this is nit-picking, but for a realistic sci-fi survival game as highly anticipated as this, I had expected the scientifically relevant aspects of the game to at least make some sense. Many of them do not :/ A prime example is the fact that whenever the player is in an underground cave, they receive the “underground” debuff which significantly affects health/stamina regen. As if it wasn’t already weird that you are debuffed simply by walking into a cave, you also risk contracting pneumonia whilst underground. Given that the player is wearing an air-tight suit (“toxic” atmosphere, remember), I am fascinated to know how airborne viruses/fungi are getting into the player’s lungs and further baffled why this can only happen underground.

There is still more to talk about with both pros and cons but I think this list at least hits some of my thoughts thus far into the game. All of the cons I’ve mentioned (and most, if not all the cons that I’ve seen other reviewers mention) are perfectly fixable problems; at this point, I'm just waiting to see if the developer is willing to put in the time and energy required to turn Icarus into the smash hit sci-fi survival game that it was advertised to be.

142729673.review: Mixed reviews apparently were of the new release. Most of those issues have been corrected. This game is great. I do single player only and so far the open world is the bomb. I have one complaint...there is no pause option. Hey devs, some of us are old and have to pee alot...we need a pause game option at least for single player.

147890663.review:
It's been a long haul for me when it comes to Icarus.
More than probably any other survival-sandbox game, I have had a love/hate relationship, in equal parts, with the world of Icarus.
As I recall, I pre-purchased this title back sometime in November of '21. This allowed a friend and I to take part in the Beta Weekends program that ran for several weeks prior to actual release. I am pretty sure it was released as full retail but it was arguably still in very early access condition.
Since game mechanics were still being implemented it would have been defined as an alpha phase game.

It was harsh, unforgiving, but strangely addictive. 
Many hours of hard work could be totally wiped out by a poorly placed torch, a random lightning strike, or the retro-engines of a coop buddy randomly being given a trajectory to enter the map that targeted directly at your camp.

Wolves could chew through multiple layers of stone construction in as little as 60 seconds.
You find yourself frequently faced with situations where you either rage-quit or simply roll over laughing hilariously at the unexpected.

It's can be that kind of harsh.

But fun!

Since I stay pretty busy with a small cadre of gaming friends who are mostly from my generation, (I am currently approaching 62 very soon.) so after release I decided that I would keep the game and check back in every so often to see how things were going with it's development. I own server hardware from which my little band of old farts play various survival-sandbox games and such as our interests lead us. Time marches on...

Now it is fast approaching Halloween for 2023 and I notice that I have around 258 hours of play under my belt from which I can form an opinion. Steam is reminding me again that I should offer up a review... so here I am.

The game is quite fetching, with a lot of natural mountain splendor, open desert vistas, and frozen wastes.
There are now enough play options and locations available from which to work feverishly on gathering resources while the local wildlife attempts to gnaw your ass off at every opportunity.

Why does the suspiciously "alligator-esque" looking crocodile seem to find me far more appealing as a dinner entree than the pretty pony, with tusks, that also wants a piece of my sweet-meats?

If you kill something, you had better dress it out in a flat-ass hurry, or hope it's small enough to throw over your shoulders and carry with you. If not, in less than 30 seconds, other denizens will come running like you rang a dinner bell.
It can quickly get out of control and you find yourself needing waders to slog your way out of the corpse pile of now dead predators you unintentionally attracted.

If... you survive.

Players are allowed to set up camp practically anywhere.

Caves are interesting, but the current mechanic is terribly janky, thoroughly breaking any semblance of believable immersion from outside weather conditions that insist on following you into the depths of the underworld in an unpredictable fashion. You can literally perish from heat stroke while suffering from frostbite inside caves that act as passageways between different biomes. The caverns seem to "want" to have their own biome but just can't manage to enforce it throughout with any dependable consistancy.
Being in a cave large enough to allow you to build a completely enclosed structure is just about your only chance against those subterranean sandstorms.

Beasts of burden have been added recently. A much needed addition to the game.
Now, if I could just convince my buffalo that "defensive" mode means it should defend itself if attacked, not go off full-Rambo at the merest sight of a possible predator in the distance.
Normally pets follow at a distance, unless they are going psycho-aggressive on a perceived intruder or if you are stopping to dress out a fresh kill. At that point they will amble over, stomp it to ensure it is dead, and then proceed to stand on the carcass in an attempt to prevent you from claiming your kill.
"Look fart-stain, you either get off my dinner or I am going to introduce you to my 'boom-stick' and make an entree substitution."

I think you all get the idea... this title is a little gem under a considerable bit of early access crustiness.
There is something to love in here, but it needs some elbow grease to make that sparkle visible.

Keep workin' on it RocketWerkz, I am a patient guy. I have nothing but time in my retirement.


~Orv

106753123.review:
Well, it has been a couple of years since my initial review.  Since steam doesn’t let you post updates without deleting anything, here is a summary of my review from 2021.

•	This game is NOT a finished product, it is literally an early access game being advertised as a full release product.
•	Very fun building and resource gathering mechanics.
•	Probably the most satisfying mechanics with using a bow.
•	Great atmosphere and sound
•	Serious performance issues without the visuals to justify it on an RTX 3090 (and my friends rigs RTX 3080’s)
•	Many half-baked features that clearly were in concept phase
•	No real alien creatures in a Sci-FI survival game…(big worms spitting at you don’t count)
•	Really dumb AI that for some reason only is interested in attacking you, and nobody else.
•	Stupidly imbalanced resource cost for advanced tier construction

Now in 2023, and for some reason, I still have a healthy love hate relationship with this dumpster fire of a game and keep coming back despite advice from my therapist.

So, how are things now, around 2 years later?

Well…like my initial review, its complicated.
There are several things I love, and a number of things I legitimately hate.

I feel I need to give this recognition, the developers have been very committed to adding new features and mechanics to this game.  They are very much weekly releasing new patches with new additions to the game.  To list some significant add-ons :-
•	Persistent Open World
•	Multiple talent tree reworks (they still aren’t perfect)
•	Revising the cost of items so its not as painful of a grind for resources anymore
•	Bestiary glossary with different weak points for creatures
•	Taming Mounts
•	Fishing
•	New missions
•	Gear attachments (no visual change however to your gear, meaning that scope you just put on your rifle…yeah, it doesn’t exist.)
•	New crafting benches
•	Horde mode style defence (however…it really shows how subpar the combat is in this game)
•	A second map with new missions and creatures (still no aliens)
•	Many new food recipes
•	Crop Farming
•	SHIELDS
•	Peer to Peer & your own hosted dedicated servers (however, very buggy)

There is to be honest, a lot that I cannot cover in this review, but it must be acknowledged that they have been actively working on this game since release, which is great.
However…

I still cannot openly recommend this game, at least, not without a discount.

There is much I would go into, but with a character limit there is only so much I can mention.
So, to get to the major points and issues I have still with this game :-

•	After approaching two years, the game still does not feel like a fully released title.  It is still an early access game, being advertised as a full release product.  If you play it for as long as I have, you can see many, many mechanics are half baked, where a potentially cool concept has been implemented but has not been implemented to a complete degree.  Useless workshop items, mounts that don’t seem to trigger mission objective progression, some missions reworked, others left very unsatisfying, etc.

•	The performance is still not acceptable.  I now have an RTX 4090, and this game still suffers from stuttering, and frame dips.  Yes, I play at 4K.  Yes, I choose not to use DLSS because I hate the distortion it causes. However, that does not excuse that I get 40-60 FPS on average with this game.  It visually at times is a pretty game, but not pretty enough to justify how poorly this game runs.  And no…after two years no Nvidia driver has magically fixed your games poor optimisation.

•	The animal AI, while they no longer stupidly decide to go ‘lets only target the humans’ and you have multiple different species of animal attacking you all at once (save for the cougar, for some reason…) they still do not act like animals.  You NEVER will see a wolf pack hunting another animal, a bear going fishing, a herd of buffalo or antelopes moving together for protection.  What do I see instead?  The alpha wolf ATTACKING ITS OWN PACK MEMBERS while I am attacking it…I have also successfully glitched the AI to have other animals attack another creature by setting it on fire, while the other animal that is set on fire just stands there and doesn’t react…(Don’t ask me how that even works).

A couple of just personal gripes from me that make me see red (and I have posted on their feedback form about…over a year ago).

•	It’s been two years…why have you still not fixed the biofuel lamp and flashlight literally failing at properly doing their job?  What I mean by that, is that the light gets obstructed by your own characters arms.  Even better, when you try to aim with a weapon like a bow, or look up and down, THEY DO NOT POINT WHERE YOU ARE LOOKING SO YOU CANT SEE! Seriously, fix this.  Its not even hard, mount the light source to over the shoulder, simple.
 
•	For the love of all that is holy, why, on Icarus, will you not tell us what the hell our actual mission objective BEFORE dropping into the planet?! Seriously, what is the actual real behind this?! This has cost me HOURS of backtracking because I do not have the right equipment, or blueprints to craft items at hand.  Some mission conditions changing due to unexpected events, that is ok.  But, when the lore behind it is we are getting contracts from entities to undertake missions on the planet, it makes ZERO SENSE why they don’t tell you what you specifically need to do!  There is zero point concealing it, people will just go and look it up on the wiki to know what to expect.  You finally added tier suggestions to missions…why are you so adamantly refusing to just tell us OUR OBJECTIVE FROM THE START

133997098.review:
I've been scrolling through reviews of this game, and the general consensus in my opinion has been mostly positive, but some negative and repeated reviews. So I wanted to throw my hat into the ring with my view of this game and the direction it has taken. For context, I had played with a friend during the trial weekends that were held before the official launch. 

This game is incredible, but is meant for a niche audience within the survival games genre group. Most survival games tend to be about construction of homes and the improvement of equipment to get rare materials. Most games, ICARUS included, follow this concept. However, some games put a spin on things (which are both good and bad features). I feel that some reviewers have missed the spin that ICARUS delivers, which is a hardtype take on the genre. 

For gameplay itself, ICARUS focuses on character importance and effects rather than how effective one's gear is. Players do not have the ability to unlock all the crafting recipes, and the player's character can either spec their talent points into being a jack-of-all-trades or a specialized character for one to two specific purposes, and there is little wiggle room. This emphasizes the benefit of having multiple people to play with, as your friends can fill in the gaps that you may not have access to. For example, I focused on farming and husbandry, while my friend was more focused on hunting and weapon perks. I enjoy this aspect purely because this enforces the notion that playing with friends makes it easier to work on specific jobs instead of trying to perform multiple tasks at once. 

ICARUS is also a game that encourages the player to focus on their character's status, as buffs and debuffs could radically change how the player operates while exploring the wilderness. They affect more than just health-related boosts. Aspects such as stamina consumption and capacity, food/water/oxygen drainage, and even experience can be affected by both buffs and debuffs. I am a huge supporter of this idea, as it enforces the concept that you can't permanently buff yourself to minimize the danger you face. 

Now that I have written down my thoughts on the gameplay, I would like to address some complaints I have seen in the reviews:

-There are complaints about the weather system being a general tumor on the community, but I disagree. Why should my crappy Thatch shack be able to withstand a storm with high-speed winds? It's made of sticks, fiber, and wood, which aren't the most durable of materials. I frankly enjoy the storm system, as it provides me with a purpose beyond plopping down some walls and roofing on some foundations and calling it a home.

-To those that say the game is poorly optimized, I do not disagree with your statements. I would prefer to view the hardware and game setting specs on reviews that are based purely on the graphics more, because I have a mid-tier laptop by today's standards and I'm running the game fine for the most part. The only time I have performance issues is when I load into a world. This is probably the only review claim that I do not fully disagree with. To those that have posted their computer specs, I thank you. 

-Finally, I've seen some reviews floating around about how predators are a joke. I agree with you that the AI could use some tuning, but you can still get your ass handed to you if you're not aware. For example, I've seen complaints about normal forest bears (which I feel have been nerfed). Bears can be a joke now, but the polar bears in the icy biomes are ruthless and aggressive. Coupled with an ill-prepared prospector that has little to no cold resistance, then you're asking to be mauled to death. Not to mention, that the debuffs that you suffer are no laughing matter. 

To summarize my thoughts on paper in a review format, this game is pretty good, especially for the price it's currently at. If you enjoy having a survival game that doesn't really hold your hand, but gives you the basic knowledge of the game functions and leaves you stranded (to a degree), then you may have fun. If you want everything to be explained in painstaking detail with little room for danger to seep in, then you should probably avoid this game.
 
P.S. If you find anything in my review that you disagree with, shoot me a comment below. I want to hear opinions from other people outside my social circle. As long as it's not to disparage me based on something you may disagree with, I'm eager to hear the thoughts of others.

144920360.review:
The game itself is actually quite decent. I'd even suggest picking it up during a sale and giving it a try. However, what really stands out in this situation is the fanservice and the way the developers handle their promises and criticisms.

Lately, on their official Discord, it seems like all they do is talk about the expenses they're dealing with to make everything happen. Frankly, it gets a bit tiresome hearing about these complaints. They only seem to be active when they're about to release something new, like New Frontiers now. Other than that, they can go for months without any communication. They're going on about how much effort and money goes into creating a pet in the game, costing anywhere from $30k to $50k, and how players don't really understand the work behind it. Then they talk about features like full mod support, which we all know breathe life into games (remember how DayZ did it?), and they claim it would cost millions. They also mention something as simple as character customization being worth a million dollars.

"Rocket | CEO" mentioned that those who bought the Supporters Edition will eventually get a significant discount. Depending on how many units are sold, the Supporters Edition might even end up not costing the developers anything, or possibly even causing them to lose money, especially in certain regions.

Honestly, this kind of messaging to the people who believed in them and invested more to receive what was promised is a bit surprising. It's common knowledge that pre-orders and early supporters often get better deals. It's not rocket science (no pun intended). It seems like they're trying to make it look like they're the ones carrying the financial burden, which doesn't really sit right. This is a standard practice, and usually, it's the other way around – pre-orders are given at a discount.

I can already imagine the defenders who will argue that we should support the developers. It's fine to have differing opinions, but we need to be honest about our concerns.

The financial equation here is quite simple. The Icarus Deluxe Edition (that was the name of the edition I bought) costs $109.98, yet Styx, which everyone owning the game received for free, has a standalone cost of $23.44 (on promotion). The first DLC, priced at $25.49, brings the total to $48.93. Even if we factor in the $8.99 for Styx and a $5.99 add-on with lamps (which is also part of the deluxe edition), the total comes to $63.91 - and the next DLC won't cost $40 for sure, does that mean they'll start slicing out every little feature and selling them for $3-4 each just to hit that price point?

The lack of transparency in their communication is baffling. Any expression of dissatisfaction is met with backlash from their supporters, who don't seem to grasp that if you don't voice your concerns, you won't see any improvements. On Discord, you're flooded with messages about how everything is perfect and fantastic, which doesn't make sense for a game that's still in development (and it's supposed to be the first year in Early Access, but that's a whole other issue).

Encountering yet another update that introduces redundant features like two shields, coupled with the ongoing lack of progress in the development of the station shop and the repeatedly emphasized but elusive focus on future improvements, has thoroughly exhausted my patience. The absence of effective communication on these matters has significantly eroded my enthusiasm. I'm left in a state of uncertainty regarding the specifics of what the next game update will bring: what content will be added and how the game will evolve. The broad statements provided often fail to align with the actual changes that emerge when an update is eventually released.

Take a look at the sudden surge in positive reviews today – it's clearly orchestrated by them.

I'm sharing this negative feedback not because I dislike the game itself, but because I'm disappointed in the way the developers are handling their communication and game development. I'd still recommend buying and playing the game. While it's notably under-optimized, the recent changes seem to make the gameplay more accessible for a wider audience. Whether it suits your tastes or not is something you'll have to decide for yourself. If they follow through with the DLC as promised, it could potentially breathe new life into the game.

150272754.review:
[h1]Icarus Review: Great Ideas, Rough Execution[/h1]

I've put some serious time into Icarus, and I've got to say, it's a mixed bag. The game's got a lot of cool ideas, but they really need to iron out a ton of kinks.

[h2]The Good Stuff:[/h2]

[list]
[*]The tech and talent trees are huge, which is awesome because you've got lots of options on how to play.
[*]The graphics are alright, and the user interface does its job without getting in the way.
[*]You can play by yourself or with friends, and there's a variety of stuff to do like timed missions, open-world survival, or outpost building.
[*]Farming materials isn't a huge grind, which I appreciate.
[*]The different crafting benches having their own inventory is a smart touch. Makes managing resources a lot easier.
[*]The crafting queue is slick and lets you stack up your crafting tasks efficiently.
[*]The shared XP system is a cool feature when you're teaming up with pals, making teamwork more rewarding.
[*]The weather effects are legit; they can get intense and make the world feel dangerously alive.
[*]The base story is interesting (even though it doesn't play much into the actual gameplay).
[*]Base building and crafting options are solid with lots of variety.
[/list]

[h2]The Bad Stuff:[/h2]

[list]
[*]Okay, the technical issues are a nightmare. Solo play is alright, but in co-op, my FPS tanks hard. We're talking dropping from 90-100 down to 15-30, and that's with a good PC.
[*]The Level of Detail (LOD) is a letdown. Even on the best settings, things pop in out of nowhere and the shadows look like they can't decide if they want to be there or not.
[*]DX12 and Ray-Tracing options seem more like they're for show because they smash your FPS and barely make a difference in how the game looks.
[*]The map is boring. There's nothing cool to find, no places that make you want to explore. No cool secrets or spots to discover, just a whole lot of "been there, seen that."
[*]The combat system is super basic. Animals just charge if you're close enough, and that's it. No dodging or parrying, and the melee is almost useless. It's all about bows or guns. There's no real skill or strategy needed, just shoot from a distance.
[*]The animals might as well have a clingy relationship with you; they follow you forever.
[*]Attack animations are rough for both the animals and the player. It's like watching early 2000s CGI trying to be real.
[*]The movement and physics feel off. Jumping feels like you're on the moon and the overall movement is just awkward.
[*]Building's got potential, but it's bogged down by a fiddly system where you craft each piece one by one and then struggle with the placement.
[*]Despite a ton of skills to choose from, a lot of them don't really matter. Like, why have multiple talents for seeing animals in bushes when one talent shows their health from afar? But there is no talent for seeing dead animals in the lush bushes...
[*]Missions could've been interesting, but they end up feeling like a grocery list of chores. It's just collecting stuff without any fun twists or challenges.
[*]The biomes look different at first, but you quickly realize they're all the same just with different skins. Plus, they're the same every time which gets old.
[*]The game's got systems like electricity, but they're only half done. There's no way to control them properly, so you're stuck playing electrician every time you need to switch something on or off.
[*]What really bugs me is that they keep dropping paid DLCs and content when there are still so many bugs and basic quality-of-life stuff that isn't fixed.
[/list]

[b]Bottom line:[/b] Icarus has some cool concepts and could be a blast, but it feels rushed. It's rough around the edges and needs some serious updates to be what it could be. If you're a survival game junkie and you've played everything else, maybe take a look. But set your expectations to "work in progress" and brace for some frustration.

[h3]Would I recommend it?[/h3]
[b][i]Only to survival game veterans looking for a new fix, and only if they've run out of options.[/i][/b]

105474655.review:
I rarely write reviews for games.

I've spent a little over 30 hours in the game at the time of this review, because I really want to give this game a fair shake and I respect the fact that Dean Hall and RocketWerkz are trying to expand the Survival genre here. I understand launch difficulties and server issues that come up around them - none of my beef with this game has anything to do with that.

The game is intentionally tedious and obtrusive in the worst possible ways. 

There are four talent trees, Survival, Construction, Combat, and Solo. The Solo tree makes no sense and forces anyone who wants to take points into it into a Solo-Only mindset, as these talents *do not work* if you are in a multiplayer game. This is a completely baffling design decision that blows my mind. The tree shouldn't exist.

There's no respec functionality whatsoever, and talent points stop at level 40. If you want to try different builds, the only solution is to make another character, which seems like an absolutely bizarre design decision without any real thought put into it. Characters are not disparate enough in terms of their talent selection to warrant alt characters, so you don't get enough of a meaningful gameplay experience change by rolling a new character to try different talents that might make your life easier. If talents were so impactful that they made the player's character feel meaningfully different from others, then I could maybe see a degree of permanence being important - but there isn't, so it makes no sense in my eyes.

Most missions follow a set formula. Land, spend 60% of your time in the mission teching back up to whatever level of technology and assets needed to complete the mission, 20% of your time completing the mission, and then anywhere from 10-20% of your total time in the mission is spent trudging back to your dropship. None of the mission timers we had ever felt like we were 'under the gun', with most missions giving anywhere from 3-7 RL days to complete, while the mission themselves took anywhere from 3-4 hours of playtime to complete. There isn't any way to facilitate faster travel aside from movement speed talents, so these last 10-20% of missions are actual wastes of time as you run through the landscape as fast as you can to get back to your dropship, so you can leave and go somewhere else - these trips can easily take up to 15-25 minutes, depending on how far the objectives are from your drop. There is nothing challenging about it - it is simply more tedium tacked on that doesn't respect the player's time.

The missions themselves are usually cased around a biome, which is a set map that you'll complete multiple missions on. This sounds fine - except for the fact that each individual mission requires you to leave the planet at the end of it. When you return to that biome to tackle a new mission, all of your building progress is gone, but the map is the exact same otherwise. On the first winter biome, we had to build virtually the *exact same base* in the *exact same spot* no less than four times because we had multiple missions for that biome. This feels incredible repetitive, doesn't respect the player's time, isn't challenging and just feels lazy.

Death is a mechanic that also makes no sense to me. In a multiplayer session, if you are killed, you drop to the ground and can be revived by a teammate. The only penalty for death in this instance is a reduction of Food / Oxygen / Water stats, which can be easily remedied. The only time you have to actually contemplate a respawn is if nobody can revive you, which in the majority of instances where you have 3 or more players, is exceedingly rare.

In solo play, this is an entirely different animal. If you are killed in solo play, you *must* respawn, and take an XP penalty as well as lose all your equipment. The dropping of the equipment is fine and understandable, but the XP penalty boggles my mind. As of the time of writing this review, the XP penalty is scaled to the amount of XP you are currently into a level. So if you're 90% of the way from level 9 to level 10, the XP penalty is HIGHER than if you were just 10% of the way into a level. If this is a bug, I'm glad to be proven wrong. Even if it isn't, the penalty is staggeringly high, and massively disincentivizes solo play.

There are other issues as well, many of which are covered in the other reviews plastered here. The Mixed aggregate of reviews is fair - the game itself has some good moments and the framework of the game is interesting. As it currently stands, I'd highly encourage prospective buyers to wait and see what RocketWerkz does to address everything. If you do still feel inclined to buy it, make sure you're playing with friends - as with most games, it's better when you have buddies to play with.

Edit:

I will say, I've given this some thought and there's a few things right off the top they could do to make things immediately better. For those of you who have upvoted and brought attention to this review, I appreciate it.



Edit: 8 June, 2022

I give Dean Hall and RocketWerkz credit - they are listening and trying.

Most of my initial suggestions (which I had to delete to conserve space) have been addressed to a reasonable degree. The new map, Styx, looks to promise some actual continuity between missions in some context (according to their devblog, missions now can change the map in between missions). The timer change to RL time makes sense, and the hardcore mode added alleviates any remaining concerns I had on that front. 

I still cannot recommend the game, but I'm a lot closer to it now than I was six months ago. It's very obvious at this stage that the staff is very committed to turning this ship around, and I've kept quiet tabs on it as they've progressed. Most of what they've addressed is core functionality of the game that was just unfun - and rightfully so, that stuff needed to be addressed first. I do think if you've read the progress and see potential with the title, it's worth investing in - but you should see it as an investment, not a game really ready to sink a ton of hours into right now.

I think they also realize that there's just not enough interesting and exciting enough incentives to actually play currently beyond chasing exotics for gear. 

What will get me back into this game is a sense of persistence. I personally want to be able to be able to land on Styx or Olympus (the two current maps) and complete *multiple* missions before returning, so I can get the benefit of not having to rebuild the same base over and over again in the same general area. Good luck, guys.

119905204.review:
Icarus is a game that I want to like, but I really have a hard time doing so.

[b]The Weather System:[/b] Arguably one of the biggest features of the game. It sounds cool, and at first is a fun thing to run into. But it quickly loses it's appeal when you realize that pretty much every type of weather just requires you to huddle in shelter until it's gone, or suffer the exposure mechanic which will kill you. And if your shelter isn't made of at least stone, it's probably going to burn down from lightning strikes.

[b]The Wildlife:[/b] Uninteresting. Simple. The passive creatures will, for the most part, sense your presence and run away, they will also run from predators if they get too close. But, despite the fear the passive creatures show, I have never actually seen a predator attack one. In fact, the only time a predator shows any interest in anything that's not human is after you've killed something, and then every carnivorous creature in a 10 mile radius is suddenly drawn to the bunny you just killed, and you have to fight all of them off in order to harvest it. The carnivorous creatures are also simple, though. They see you? They try and eat you. I've had bears, crocodiles and wolves working together chasing me through the water to kill me. There's no territorial aggression between species, they all just serve to kill you.

[b]Travel:[/b] A large portion of the game. And also probably the most boring part. The majority of the missions I've done, and I have not done all of them, require a lot of running from point to point. The last mission I just completed was to open up a path to make travel between an area easier. But what was required to open that path had so much time wasting filler that it wasn't even fun. And also to note, these steps are told individually after you complete the previous one. There's zero indication, unless you look up the mission steps ahead of time, that these will be required.
[list]
[*]Step 1: Land on the planet, retrieve the radar from your dropship, scan three locations. In classic Icarus fashion, each area you scan causes wildlife to attack you.
[*]Step 2: Once all three locations are scanned, (which are pretty spread out and take a while to get to each) you have to head over to a cave that was picked up by the scanning.
[*]Step 3: Gain access to the cave, which requires backtracking down the snowy mountainside  that you had just gone through to scan one of the areas in order to retrieve explosives dropped for you.
[*]Step 4: Once you've retrieved the explosives, head back up to the cave you found and place them.
[*]Step 5: Once those explosives are placed, you're told you need to go to the other side of the cave in order to place them on the opposite side. The 'legitimate' path to do that requires you to circle the entire map, and then cut through the desert straight back south to place the explosives on the other side of the cave, too.
[*]Step 6: Once you've done that, mission is over and you can extract.
[/list]
But, to add onto all of the above steps, a weather system starts every 5 minutes and lasts between 5-10 minutes of having to wait through it in shelter. And between running for the 5 minutes of time without weather, you've gotta kill every wolf, bear, boar, cougar, hyena, scorpion and whatever other hostile creature I'm forgetting to mention because they'd all aggro onto you as you pass by.
But to top it all off, the reward for this mission was garbage in comparison to the one I'd done previously for not even half the effort or time.

TLDR; Unfortunately the game suffers from far too much time-wasting filler and lack of interesting mechanics, despite initially seeming like it should be interesting. The game can certainly be fun, but at the end of the day I think there are better survival games out there, and I personally would not suggest this one to any of my friends.

105537542.review:
First of all, just to be clear, I don't recommend this game YET. I get the feeling that given some work, Icarus potential may be met, and there is a ton of potential here. But in it's current state, there is a lot of disappointment.

[b]My biggest issue with Icarus is it doesn't seem to take it's own identity seriously.[/b] Its stake in the survival gaming world, its gimmick if you will, that you're not sticking around, you get in, build what you have to and get out, its quite invigorating and a great take on a survival crafter. But as I have followed Icarus through beta it seems like more and more it aims to try to keep you around longer than you should have to be. Furthermore, mechanics that aimed to put that type of manic pressure have been either removed or pseudo-removed, I say "psuedo", as the timer for missions is still very much implemented, but 7 days ([i]real days[/i], not in game days) is not exactly pushing you out the door even for the most casual of players. It's all kind of a wash and many likely play through there 20 or so levels gathering different components to craft higher level gear in the first or second prospect (Icarus' name for missions) and don't bother pursuing the others.

And why would they? [b]Higher level craftables are insanely expensive and completely unnecessary given that the "second best" option in many cases is nearly as good if not pretty much identical to the far more expensive top item. [/b]This is compounded by the fact that the game expects you to get comfortable with a play loop for its prospects but offers almost nothing unique or interesting to do once you get to them. It feels really bad to spend an hour or two building the same stuff you've already built a dozen times to do a mission that then asks you to do little more than touch a couple flowers and leave, no weapons, armor, proper preparation of any kind was necessary in the first place. This had me treating most prospects as trial and error. Lets try to do the mission, if I die, we build some stuff, if not, we just leave. But this feels very counterintuitive to the gameplay loop Icarus WANTS to establish.

I know everybody has a bucket list but I'd like to offer some things I personally would like to see implemented I think would alleviate some of this general unfun grind and allow for some far better experiences. It doesn't sit well with me to just say "this bad" and offer no alternative.

1. [b]Combine some of the prospects together.[/b] This one is integral as far as I'm concerned. There is no sense in grinding a house and upper level crafting stations for upwards of an hour to play for 15 minutes. Claiming there are 36 missions is a stretch, of the 10 or so I've done through release and the beta there's more like 1 mission and 9 bloated side stories. Just taking the first 3 forest biome propects alone, if you were to drop, have to gather some exotic tea leaves, plant some radar stations and hunt down a scary predator all in one mission, with a timer of say more like 6 hours instead of 6 days... holy moly we're playing a fricken game now. [i]It's almost like we could potentially fail[/i], like there is something at stake. A vital aspect this game is missing.

2. [b]Electronics need to be nerfed or just removed, and then and only then the "second best" needs to be nerfed in almost every category.[/b] This isn't just tools and weapons mind you, the ice box can run for an Icarus eternity on a handful of ice and preserves food what seems like triple or better. This is already fantastic, and makes the much, much more difficult to craft and run refrigerator, frankly a joke. The dev (devs?) already lowered some crafting costs but seem wary of making any sweeping changes, which is totally fair, however I'd say also completely necessary in this case. EDIT: As of 12/10, the devs have also buffed gold spawn, which was by far the biggest pain point for resource gathering. However that has done little to aid the the mind-numbing amount of materials necessary for some crafts, even if they are more readily available. My rant is reduced, but the following statement still holds true. [u]Have fun farming for 12+ hours to make your compound bow and composite arrows that you will likely leave behind after the 20 minutes it takes for you to complete the mission.[/u] This is a serious problem.

3. I've played solo and with a team and there is an unfair disadvantage to players who either do both or exclusively play solo. [b]The solo tree should get talent points every level[/b]. Obviously still turn them off during team play, but allow leveling solo and group trees together. The separation of the trees is actually implemented quite nicely, the fact that you must choose is atrocious.

4. [b]Talent respec please[/b]. Especially if the talent tree is not going to recieve points beyond 40, there is not enough variation in builds to warrant walling this without making a completely new character, and in modern games spending those 3 or 4 points in something that did not have the impact you expected and having NO viable way to undo that action is rough to say the least. I don't care if it costs in game currency to still slightly discourage, I'm fine with that, but SOMETHING to respec talent system please.

5. This is more of a refinement to the speeding up gameplay to match what Icarus is all about but how about some better exotic offerings. It takes about 10 minutes to get in a craft a steel pickaxe and about 10 seconds to craft a campfire but up to 2 hours to craft something I'd really LIKE to use like a dehumidifer. How about a darn exotic dehumidifer so I can drop in and cave base. In the absence of some way to bring items back with you (which would sure be nice, even if just 1 or 2), I'd really think the game would know itself well enough to supply you the good stuff  in its end game meta progression and not extremely minor benefits that barely speed up gameplay at all. An icebox, a furnace, a stove, SOMETHING you actually want. Or just let us keep it. You know how much better I'd feel about crafting that stupid compound bow and a full stack of composite arrows if I could KEEP them? Much better. Maybe THIS (exotic storage container?) is something worthwhile to throw on the lackluster exotic tree.

[h1]Conclusion, TL:DR[/h1]

I know a lot of this sounds like "make Icarus harder!" no wait "make Icarus easier!" but that's a lot of how I feel about the games current state. Things that should be difficult like the prospect objectives are disappointingly simple especially if you put any effort into preparing that prospect. While others that should flow with Icarus' time based missions are dummy hard like crafting anything made of composites. And this isn't good difficulty, its tedium which Icarus is currently full of and really doesn't have to be. At least these two problems bandage each other, I guess. Had missions been tougher this would make crafting necessary top level stuff just feel all the worse. Instead most will simply never even experience that content because its relegated as unnecessary. But this seems a shame to me, and can't possibly be what the developer intended.

Here's to bettering Icarus, I really like this game all the frustrations aside, I hope to recommend it and even love it in the future.

108256335.review:
Over 150 hours played so far and I left a negative review. It doesn't make sense...just like this game.  I want to like it.  Parts of it are great.  I know it could become something really awesome.  The foundation is there. Then a bear runs up a vertical cliff and destroys me as I get stuck in the map...with pneumonia...but I have on a spacesuit with its own oxygen supply.

The game does not run well even on new hardware.  The grind is awful just for the sake of being awful.  There is no balance to any of the crafting costs or Tiered equipment.  Enemy AI is ridiculous but not in a funny way.  There is usually no point to getting anything beyond the lowest tier gear and sprinting (vast distances) to the objective unless you are forced to craft T4 gear just to complete the mission immediately afterward and start all over again on the next one.  My character is almost level 90 but I stopped getting talent points 50 levels ago and will never be able to learn the art of turning wood into sticks. There is almost no point to exotics, yet they are described as the most valuable thing on Icarus.  Cheese tactics usually prevail in any situation.

And despite all of this, I grind on, searching endlessly for gold and I guess sticks as well because my character will never know the joy of converting the wood I chopped into sticks that I need stacks and stacks of to get a drop of that sweet bio fuel and those shiny electronics parts.  I just imagine that it will all be worth it in the end...or when the DLC continues the story even though there are current in game items labeled as "coming soon".  I don't know what to think of this game but most people probably won't like it.  Except for my one friend who joins prospects to make sticks for me.  I think he likes it...maybe.

EDIT 3/2/2022: Talent points and leveling have been improved with the recent update.  I CAN MAKE STICKS NOW.  Finally an update that starts to resolve the real issues with this game.  Also drop ship inventory has been increased, making workshop items worthwhile to unlock.

EDIT 4/14/2022: Negative points for generic copy-paste developer response, not addressing anything specifically mentioned in my review.

EDIT 11/2022:  Open World mode seems promising...50 weeks after release.

EDIT 3/2023: Above review is still accurate.  Devs treat this like it's still early access, over a year after release.
