130258083.review:
I don't usually write heartfelt reviews for games.

ICARUS is one of the most creative, interesting, and engaging games that I will never recommend to anyone.

This game is the epitome of catching lightning in a bottle and then putting the bottle in your attic, never to be seen again. So many creative ideas and concepts feel half finished, poorly implemented or terribly balanced. I can see how this game could have, and still might be, one of the greats of the survival gaming genre, but at the current rate with the direction of updates that Rocketwerks' creative team seems to be taking, they are turning this game into the most average open world survival experience. 

The premise of this game is that you are a semi independent contractor, doing jobs on a failed terraforming project for research, economic, and military applications. This failed terraforming project for some reason or another has caused the atmosphere to be completely unbreathable for humans, and with the lack of any real and established presence for full scale colonization or production from orbit, you are dropped in to do these jobs with the clothes on your back and a sense of optimism. You will need to source all of your equipment by yourself (or with friends), from the planets surface every mission. This is without a doubt one of the main draws of this game for myself and one of the reasons I loved it so much. This system, of continual restarts in an almost quasi-roguelike open world system was very well done. 

However, after your first few missions you will start to hit a massive wall. All of the late game tech (tier 3 and 4 in the game's 4 tier system) is HORRIFICALLY balanced to a point where doing them in a mission is not at all worth it. For basically every mission in this game that doesn't include fighting a world boss or dealing with polar bears, you can deal with practically any threat with the tier 1 bow. It doesn't help that most of the animal AI in this game is borderline mentally disabled to a degree where if it is a passive, prey animal it will most likely run directly away, and if its a carnivore, it will immediately turn and try to kill you on sight. If you even have the slightest amount of game sense you can predict basically all your shots, and easily dodge animals like grizzly bears by simply moving slightly to the left or right. However you will never see a carnivore try to kill anything other than you. In fact all the animals literally have zero interaction with each other in the environment around you. Speaking about the environment, remember how you were on a planet that had an unbreathable atmosphere, so you had a space suit? Get ready for that to never matter - the only fucking interaction you will ever have in this game that will remotely remind you of this fact is a little oxygen indicator you need to keep filled, which ends up being nothing but a glorified timer for how long you can be away from your base for. This spacesuit will never rip or crack, even though it apparently lets you catch pneumonia from caves (even though I have a filtered oxygen supply?) and take massive, bleeding gash wounds from all the dangers on this hostile planet. This somewhat haphazard thinking and implementation is what plagues this game and often seeps into its systems and development. Another great example would be the complete random spread of biomes, with no crossover or realistic mediums between them - a massive glacier area is literally bordering 2 fucking deserts in the main map. It would be more interesting if there were additional maps that had a more biome focused region, maybe one that is tropical into a coastal area, a steppe type region that blends into a desert, a more northern coniferous forest type that merges with a cold northern arctic blend. I think this would not only add to the scale of the game's world, but allow for more interesting biome interactions that don't border on nonsensical.

And this is just the tip of the iceberg. Realistically, I have a list 20 miles long of things that this game needs to fix or implement better. Which brings me to my next point - the devs have a broken game that needs to be fixed, and they will not do it in lieu of adding simple stupid weekly one-shot items and systems in these cheesy weekly updates. Instead of optimising the game (which by the way will have massive lag spikes even with top of the line cards and processors, god forbid you get a wildfire, which will basically shoot you down to 4 fps if you're lucky AND have a good system) they seem to only want to add more, new content. Content is not bad, but the issue is they're adding it to a game that doesn't need it. This game needs optimization, general redesign, balance fixes, etc. These are things the community has been requesting for almost a year and a half but it feels like its falling on deaf ears, to a point now where it feels like they are slowly changing the game to be a shadow of its former self in the idea that the criticism received is due to the game's core systems and gameplay instead of its piss poor performance on gaming rigs. 

But honestly I could forgive all of this. Even though this game has so many critical issues, if it wasn't for the fact they gutted the asynchronous online multiplayer feature, and seem to be starting to look to abandon this game. I think they don't understand that their fans want quality not quantity when it comes to updates and now they seem to just be adding random shit for the hell of it, instead of focusing on developing the culture around this game and turning it into the cult classic title in the survival genre it could easily be. 

Don't buy this game unless Rocketwerks fundamentally changes their approach to this game's development. You're better off in the hands of Iron Gate Studios with something like Valhiem. They at least give a shit about their game, and understand it's mechanics and systems, which is more than what I can say for the devs of this one.

I really, really hope that this game will change for the better and I'll get to say I was wrong. 

But I doubt it.

106323976.review:
Tl;dr this is an early access game masquerading as a complete game with some interesting mechanics but is about as unbaked as your aunties homemade minced meat pie after a hard night of boxed white wine - get it on sale for $5 and play with some friends in a year or two when (if?) the developers get around to finishing the game.

Good stuff first since it's a short list:
 - There's a nice big old talent tree with tons of awesome looking talents, which is one of the things I find survival games [i]never[/i] have. If they do have them they're anemic as shit, where as this game has multiple trees with really nice looking QoL perks. Sadly, you won't get to use more than 15% of it (more on that in the negatives....).
 - When the game doesn't run at 20-30 FPS on a 2080 TI @2k, it's beautiful. Best of luck finding a guide that helps you figure out which options decimate the engine and then praying they actually work. On the other hand, I'm genuinely impressed (technically speaking) that a company managed to find a way to make Unreal run [b]worse[/b] than Unity for an FPS.
 - The building and crafting is fun despite all of the various issues with both. Making bases is enjoyable, the multiple tables are nice, progression makes more or less sense (though it's stupidly expensive and grindy)
 - Despite being an awful grindy overall experience it's still somehow fun to play with friends, at least until you get to the end game missions and realize that you spent $27 on a running/mining simulator with combat mechanics implemented by a toddler
 - Some cool save-game tech; your game ('prospect') gets uploaded somewhere central any [b]anyone[/b] you were playing with can resume it, at any time, and play it with or without you. This is a great approach since there's no real time limit in-game for completing things (just real-life time), so people can play at their leisure and make progress.

Transitioning to the cons...:
 - Nothing is explained. Apparently, everyone was expected to play the two previous betas/open events and know what all the gameplay mechanics were, how the missions worked, that your character gets permanently deleted if you don't finish (or abort) a mission in X real-time days (yup!), that exotics (the end game in-game currency to buy cool unique "workshop" items) require a specific quest chain to unlock (the game now highlights these missions after some patches, at least).
 - Sometimes your cool unique workshop items get deleted and you lose them and have to repurchase them. No, not because you left them behind on a mission, because the game just decided to delete them. Why does this suck? Because they require in-game rare currencies (either golden dollars or purple exotic dollars) that come in small quantities from grinding missions and [i]aren't supposed to get deleted[/i].
 - The talent trees are huge but you stop getting points at level 40. This gives you enough points to get 2 trees pretty filled out, but since you had no idea this was going to happen, you've got points spread out over random ass trees all over the place as you were having fun exploring. Naturally, though, you can respec - oh wait, the developers have never played a game with a talent tree before so that's not implemented either. Coming soon (TM), though!
 - The AI is about as smart a lobotomized penguin and all of the animals behave exactly the same. Prey runs and comes back to the [b]exact[/b] same spot you shot it, so hunting amounts to either 1) crit and 1-shot everything, 2) don't crit, wait for animal to pat back to you then murder it with a crit. Predator combat is either 1) bring more friends and pincushion it down with arrows, 2) crit and 1-shot everything except polar bears, 3) if it's a polar bear, crit it and glitch past it or unstuck and get teleported 15 feet away and re-engage, 4) get glitched and 1-shotted yourself when the enemy is 15 feet away and contemplate all the other things $27 could have got you (have you even tried Wendy's new breakfast sandwiches? $27 is a [b]lot[/b] of sandwiches!).
 - The game runs like crap and it seems to be on a completely random basis; find a guide on Youtube and pray it has an affect on your FPS.
 - Dropping items on the ground sometimes falls them through the planet, deleting them permanently, because this game is [strike]fully baked and released[/strike] early access
 - Crafting at later tiers is abysmal. For example, end-game benches require 40-80 gold, and on average you'll maybe get 40-80 gold ore (crafted 2:1 into ingots) from tier 2/3 mines. You need a lot of benches. This basically means all of the end-game is: run around the map decimating every mine (which have fixed amounts of ore, doesn't respawn), then hope to god you can craft the benches to make the mission materials you need at which point you then fuck off back to space and lose 100% of your progress only to do it all again in the next mission.
 - Crafting in general is just terrible. We don't tech beyond bows for weapons or basic bone arrows for ammo as all it does is force you to play the same mission longer, re-grinding the materials you used for either item. The game is also of course very realistic - an aluminium arrow (1, mind you) naturally takes 1 copper ingot, 4 aluminum ingots, and some epoxy. Yes, 4 aluminium ingots. If you've never Googled what an "ingot" of metal is, today is the day you should, then Google "arrow head" and try to wrap your head around how they fit 4 ingots of aluminium in one arrow.
 - Playing without friends is a nightmare; play with friends or wait until the devs address solo play. It's just taking the already massive grind and multiplying it by the lack of friends you have.
 - While mining in a cave you get a permanent stamina debuff no matter what armor you are wearing, because [i]immersion[/i]. You also randomly develop pneumonia, which there is a later-game fix for, but no one cares because all it does is make you take 15 minutes versus 10 to grind out the mind-numbingly boring cave mining expedition.
 - Fun fact: 100 stones in a pile weighs far more than 100 stones in your inventory, because the stone pile is full of extra [i]stone pile juice.[/i]
 - Dying in the beginning is awful (massive XP debuff you have to work through), dying after level 40 is 100% completely irrelevant as XP no longer matters at all.

It's got potential. Somehow, despite all of that awful experienced, I almost clocked 60 hours and that was largely playing with 1-2 other people. With more I'm sure the grind would be less noticeable.

This definitely feels like a come-back-in-a-few-years kind of game and see if the developers have got around to completing it. Right now it's just frustrating and unrewarding.

107442907.review:
The game is solid and entertaining until level 40 when all the idiocy of the developers is shown in all it's glory. The talent tree is very extensive with a solo only and a party tree, but you only get talent points up to level 40. This normally wouldn't be an issue, however with such an extensive talent tree I would expect MANY more than 40 levels of points. I don't think 100 would even be enough. 

Now for the worst part. The deal-breaker. It's impossible to re-specialize. With less than 40 levels of points and no knowledge of the limited cap, you are 100% forcing every player who buys your game to make a new character once they hit level 41. NO ONE WANTS TO DO THIS IN A SURVIVAL CRAFTING GAME. The average player does NOT play survival crafting games for longer than 50-70 hours. Expecting every player to restart around that time is absolutely ridiculous. 

I had fun until level 41. The moment I leveled and realized I got no talent points, I logged out and paid a visit to google. Once I found out I couldn't re-specialize I uninstalled and haven't looked back. If I could refund, I would.

137966701.review:
This game is really hard to review.

I grabbed this game when it came out and was immediately immersed into the amazing graphics and environmental realism.  After 20 or so hours I was really enjoying the single player loop.  Two years ago, the construction was really innovative.  Coming from Valheim, Fallout 76, 7 Days to Die, and other then-recent base-building games, I really liked what they were doing here.  It felt grounded and realistic and had a real sense of PLACE.  Something about the way storms rolled in and shook your entire cabin while you cowered inside in the firelight... it was amazing.  The weather system forced you to take breaks, to actually spend time inside, and therefore you want to make your base interesting, attractive, and useful.  You really wanted your base to be AESTHETIC as well as situated usefully.  Some of the early bases I built still stay in my mind, like an old college apartment.

Hunting (before assists were available) was a matter of walking quietly through the forest and paying attention to your surroundings (I still recommend NOT unlocking the assists, or hunting turns into running through the forest looking for health bars, and automatically landing headshot after headshot without even seeing your target...).  At any moment you could come upon a predator that would wipe you out.  It was tense and atmospheric.  There was one particular mission where you have to gather an absurd amount of food to return to orbit.  In one area, you have to hunt, and in another you need to farm.  That one mission took me about 30 hours in single player.  When I was a kid there was a forest near my house that my friends and I would spend every day exploring (bear with me).  I mapped every nook and stump in the forest in my head.  Until this game, I'd never experienced that same feeling from a video game.

I made burnfields to chase the animals into valleys so I could hunt more efficiently.  I created towers and raised boardwalks to spot valuable prey and sight dangers from a safe height.  The other base was a total contrast, a fortress of farming.  Before taking to orbit, I even felt compelled to ceremoniously burn my house for closure.  It just felt more right than abandoning it, after spending so much (real) time using it as a home.  Note I started calling it a 'home' and not a base.

I talked my friends into getting it and we spent over 120 hours together in this game.  It saw us through much of the pandemic years.  Unfortunately, none of us have any desire to play it anymore.  Why?

Well, the same things that made it compelling are fatal flaws.  After one, two, 20 times through the loop of building a base, only to leave it and start again... it felt less like making an outpost and more like busywork.  The hollowness of the game started to peek through.  The fact that there are 4 variations on a cave, and you've seen them all by mission 2.  The fact that the predators ignore the prey and run straight for you (even to the point that deer and bears can sometimes literally RUN INTO each other and get stuck, causing pathfinding problems as they try to jump over each other in an absurd and very Bethesda way).  The fact that necessary high-tier items can take literal days to accumulate resources for, and you can't keep anything for the next mission.  What do you call a 'reverse-roguelike'? 

In the early versions of the game, mission timers ran in real time - as in, start a mission on Friday, you better finish it by Sunday or you lose both the mission and your entire character!  It was a strange design choice, but one you could respect as it framed the game in a unique way.  It demanded a commitment that saw me and my friends log on night after night.  This is hard to maintain in reality, but did contribute to the immersion and significance of the time spent.

Unfortunately this flawed vision really left no roadmap for the developer.  They compromised on some of the stranger decisions (like the real time mission timer), but the game was built with that in mind, so removing it removed meaning from the overall experience that they haven't been able to replace.  It is a game designed to be played one way, that never truly realized that vision, and is now wandering in a different direction, and therefore full of contradictions and broken ideas.  Some of the most fundamental design problems have not been addressed, while the developer seems dedicated to continuously releasing heartfelt but ultimately trivial weekly updates.  Somehow they are adding content while the game keeps feeling smaller and less important.

In short, the game really never came together.  There is clear genius leading up to the game's release - an ultimately unfinished but promising early access game.  Since then, however, that same genius has been completely absent.  Its like a song where they only wrote the refrain.  Its so disappointing, because at moments the game was not only my GOTY, but one of my favorite games of all time.  There are also many great memories made with IRL friends that this game helped create.   Its odd to go from enthralled to repelled, but that's the journey, and I think that ambivalence is scattered throughout many of the reviews you'll read.  It honestly makes me regret this game more than a game that just bored me.  Or maybe I should say I'm not mad, Icarus.  I'm just really, really disappointed.

154861507.review:
I'm giving this a soft yes.

Icarus is like [i]Valheim[/i] and [i]Ark: Survival Evolved[/i] had a baby who ran off wanting to do its own thing.

The game was originally envisioned as a mission-based Open World Survival Crafting game with a twist: every new mission is a fresh start. In a somewhat roguelite fashion, your mission rewards can be used to upgrade your starting equipment for future missions, but every mission drops you into a fresh iteration of the world and you have a timer to get your job done and leave. The timers are quite generous, but ultimately all your work on-world gets wiped at the end of each mission and each new one starts with the same humble beginnings, meeting basic needs and working up the tech tree.

This means you are doing the early stages of OWSC play over and over again.

The addition of Open World play allows players like me who want to explore and build in a persistent world the ability to do so. A majority of the missions are available to Open World players through "Operations" (although some are locked off, such as resource-stockpiling missions). Additionally, many of the missions give you free tech that will bolster your progress if playing in Open World. (If you are playing through Missions the classical way where you leave the planet after each mission, sorry, you can't take those goodies with you.)

The missions, however, do not come with any sort of story. They are just "go do this thing". There are multiple factions in play, but you never get any feeling for any of them. The developers finally started correcting this with the second major DLC: New Frontiers. The missions on that map actually have a story and provide some much needed lore. Which is one of the reasons that DLC is the best that the game has to offer. The lore is scant, the story is shallow, and there are no choices that would elevate this to horizon's-distance of being an RPG. But it is [i]something[/i]. And that is much better than nothing.

As a sandbox, it is a good game that I spent hundreds of hours playing. The mechanics are solid. It doesn't egregiously waste my time (although I really wish there was some sort of fast travel system between bases). I found the talent trees very nicely done, with some very cool talents to work towards (like javelins glowing to allow you to retrieve them easily or planted crops not decaying once grown). Praise-worthy decision by the devs to have levels also give you separate solo talent points to put into extra boosts for playing solo that offset the difficulties for someone trying to take on a game meant for multiplayer alone. And the tech tree was fun to climb. I really appreciated when talents or blueprints unlocked alternate recipes, such as allowing making rope out of leather or gunpowder out of fertilizer. 

On the other hand, some of the mechanics need work. Base building is often frustrating as pieces refuse to snap to other pieces or will do so in every orientation except the one you want. Oxygen and water containers will equip to your hotbar rather than your suit's life support slots. And one cursed site I tried to build on had terrain that wasn't actual terrain -- just invisible walls and blanketing textures in proximity to each other.

And yes, there were bugs. Not too often, although more often than I prefer to see. Sometimes beneficial. Occasionally, I would stop consuming oxygen and water. Or have shotgun shells spawn in my inventory. Sometimes detrimental. On rare occasion, one or two pieces of a base would fail to load. A base I had worked on for over a hundred hours was destroyed by a glitch followed by a crash. And sometimes just bizarre, such as weather-damaged trees becoming invisible or the lava cave where creatures from the land above would regularly drop through the ceiling and land in the lava flow. With the exception of the glitch-n'-crash base-obliteration, none of these were significant.

The world is beautiful: lovingly hand-crafted map with an RNG factor for various resources. We are given small number of biomes: forests, deserts and arctic zones. As a lover of base building in OWSC games, I was drawn to the waterfalls of the forests and the desert oasis beauty of the canyons in the original map. My ultimate home on the Prometheus map was a cliffside manor built across a majestic waterfall such that the water flowed through the house.

The world is not exotic, which is fitting for a terraformed planet meant to be a second earth, but ultimately to the game's detriment. It is all very familiar. You traveled lightyears and dropped onto a planet from a space station to hunt deer and boars. The Styx map from the first big DLC gives you more of the same, with a few added creatures. The Prometheus map from New Frontiers takes real steps to remedy this by providing some more exotic scenery and color filters, making it the most interesting map to play on as well as the most rewarding. But I never felt the game developers went far enough. The opening sequence had hints of more, with its giant flowers in lakes of blood and alien creatures scampering through darkened woods. But the game doesn't live up to that. 

Save for the extremely rare boss monster, the most dangerous threats are bears. 

Granted, bears in Icarus are effing [i][b]scary.[/b][/i]

But they're not alien or exotic or particularly... special. And I suppose I was really looking for more. 

Which sums up the entire experience of Icarus. Good, fairly solid, and the devs deserve praise for some cool design choices. Worth buying. Worth playing. But ultimately it falls short of what it could be, or at least what I was hoping it would be.

105176522.review:
[h1]The fact that we as gamers can't tell the difference between an "Early Access" and "Full Release" title these days should be unacceptable[/h1] 

[i] [h1] "But Joe, how is this not a full release?" [/h1] [/i]
[i]A few of my PC specs for reference: 2080Ti, i7-8700k, 32GB of RAM [/i]

Oh boy, I don't even know where to begin but let's name a few reasons:

- For a full release title, performance is [b]absolutely terrible[/b]. I've spent well over [i]ten[/i] hours trying to find reasonable settings and I still haven't found it yet.

- Multiple "coming soon" crafting items [b]AND[/b] missions. If this is a full release game, there is absolutely no reason to have something labelled "coming soon" unless the game isn't in a finished state.

- Several errors left in the game that [b]LITERALLY SAY[/b] [i]"beta state only"[/i]

- The games description on Steam mentions [i]"Explore a savage [b]alien[/b] wilderness in the aftermath of terraforming gone wrong"[/i]. The only thing in the game that is alien is a cave worm, a bigger cave worm (boss) and Oxite. Everything else is earthbound: pumpkins, berries, carrots, squash, watermelon, etc. The wildlife? Wolves, bears, cougars, hyenas, fish, elephants, zebras, etc. Not a single thing here is alien. 

- If you go back and take a look a their earlier announcement trailers, you'll notice [b]SEVERAL[/b] actual alien creatures, including VEHICLES! None of that is present in their "full release game". If your defense to this one is "they said it'll be added in later" then you've proved the entire point of this review.

- Animal levels in the game have zero purpose outside of a few extra XP given. They don't do more damage and they don't have more health. 

- Missions are clearly copy/pasted and rushed. Go to three areas, scan them, leave (or close to that same formula). 

- Outposts [i](aka sandbox mode)[/i] completely leave out predators, ultimately handicapping you on essential resources for advancement. No option is given to add those predators into the game at any point. Considering the desert biome is mostly predators, I can only imagine how empty that biome actually is in sandbox mode.

Devs, I appreciate the free key and effort you've put into this game so far and I will admit there is a fun game sitting here. This isn't your fault, the project leads failed you on this one and rushed it out for holiday sales. Shame on them releasing this as a Full Release title.

[h1]Comments regarding my play time:[/h1]

Yes, I left a review at 1.4 hours. It didn't take long to see this wasn't a finished game. Yes I continued to play for ~30 more hours. To those who feel this invalidates my review, that's fine. For those looking to understand [i]why[/i]; I spent ~10 hours troubleshooting looking for the "my game runs fine" middle ground I kept seeing in the comments. Needless to say, the game still runs horribly. I continued to play beyond those extra troubleshooting hours because there IS something fun about the game. I can't tell what, but there is a foundation there for something great. 

I also wanted to see what else the game had to offer. To see if things got better. I think that's fair. If anything the fact that I [i]STILL[/i] don't recommend this game after sinking more time into it should further valid my review. I gave it a fair shot.

[h1] Comments regarding me getting the game for free[/h1]

I've been reading comments mentioning that [i]"I don't get to have an opinion"[/i] simply because I received this game for free. I encourage you to think a bit differently regarding your stance. The fact I have received a game for free doesn't mean it automatically receives a positive review. If that was the case, you'd never get an honest review. If I'm recommending against this game despite getting a free key, that should speak volumes to you.

[h1] In response to the Developer comment:[/h1]

This is typical PR speak. If we can just keep it real with each other, everyone would benefit from honesty and transparency. You failed to reassure me or anyone else. You managed to admit nothing outside of you [i]"feel confident the game is still in a 1.0 state"[/i], yet in the very next sentence you state [i]"expect to see a lot of patches, tweaks and updates over the following days, weeks, and months."[/i] but what you described is [b]exactly[/b] what an early access game is. 

Don't get me wrong, I'm on board with you all fixing the game. However this is an incredibly misleading and dangerous tactic to advertise your game as a full release when it is nowhere close to being full release.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

If I had to take a guess, they fell behind on development, bought basic assets for resources/ animals and tossed it into the game either as the final cut or as placeholders until they can actually finish the game. They labelled it full release because they wanted to avoid the stigma "early access"  brings. This is easily comparable to the original launch of No Man's Sky; Over promised, under delivered, fix later. 

[h1] This is not acceptable and shouldn't be to you either. It's ok if you enjoy the game, but you should be more objective when it comes to identifying a games problems if you want games to be better. If we want better games, we need to expect better and be better. [/h1]
105176522.developer_response:
Hey! Firstly - thank you for your feedback, we do appreciate the time you took to write this, and I'd love to give you some insights in return. 

Firstly, absolutely hear your concerns about the 'Early Access vs Full Release' being a murky grey area, and no-one enjoys bugs, so apologies on your experiences there! We've pushed out a couple of hotfixes so far since release, and have another one coming which will address a few more. We feel confident the game is still in a 1.0 state, but don't plan on leaving it to suffer at the hands of some unintentional bugs or balancing issues, so expect to see a lot of patches, tweaks and updates over the following days, weeks and months. 

The performance and optimisation are also definitely acknowledged areas of concern. We've got more optimisations coming to try and improve performance even further, but this game does require a stronger rig than most standard titles. One thing I would highly recommend is trying DX11 instead of DX12, we're aware of some issues there. Also fiddling with the settings before hopping into game has worked for a lot of people, let me know if either work for you!

While we did have our recommended specs on the store page, we could definitely do more to communicate these, and help provide a simpler process for players to get the most out of the game. Leave that with us - lots to come in this space, Icarus is here to stay :)

Again, thank you for the feedback!

Cheers

- Shammgod

111898681.review:
With around 200 hours into this game and being like lvl 90ish (they recently capped the view to 50 so I can't see my real level anymore :( ), I've pretty much seen it all. As of March 9, 2022, This game is still in beta. Don't believe it when they say it's in full release because it's not. They never finished the story, progression is boring af, and it feels as though the game lacks direction. Heck, they are still trying to add missions... you know that core component of a game that uses missions for levels to play on. It's one thing for a game to lack polish, but it was missing core features and content that should have been available on release. Eh, it's all semantics anyways right? But it just feels icky since some people won't buy a game if it's not in full release because they don't want to play an unfinished game... and it's as though in order to save their asses, the leadership team at Rocketwerkz pushed it into full production to keep the money rolling in. The move seriously lacks morals and integrity.

Now don't get me wrong... there's a reason why I keep coming back to this game, because it's so damn beautiful. I pretty much play on max/epic settings, and the environment absolutely draws you in. I often will sit inside my Icarus house and look out a window at the lake and mountain range and it feels peaceful. The exploration, mining, and crafting will draw you in if you're into those things. Crafting has a lot of imbalances. Some items you'll have a very hard time finding a use for, nor will you likely craft probably 1/4 of the items ever, unless you craft them just for the heck of it. They make crafting tier 4 items pretty much a grind to find copper and gold. And to get the OP workshop items, it's just a grind for Exotics... which there's really only 1-way to grind them which is 300% more efficient than doing other missions for them. The aggro mobs are uber meh; extremely simple aggro mechanics...run in a straight line at you and swing. If they didn't have skins you wouldn't be able to tell a difference between them at all.

I give the criticism out of love not hate. I want this to be a great game. It's just a game with a beautiful environment that lacks damn near everything. Can I recommend it? The part of me that dislikes half-assed work says no. I can't give a recommendation solely on graphics. I hope this helps.

118673505.review:
While there are many aspects of the game that are enjoyable, (base building, missions etc) the game requires too much effort for not enough reward, and is ultimately far too punishing, and often for no reason. The animal spawns seem random at best, and more often than not the entire region seems out for the player's blood. The gameplay loop of starting from scratch every mission makes everything feel very slow, and since you can't take anything with you when you leave, (unless you brought it from space to begin with) you spend much of your time just getting back to a decent level. And if you want to make some of the top tier items, you will need to pour hours into running around gathering hundreds of semi-limited supplies, such as 180 copper bars, (360 ore) just to make two machines who's sole purpose is to make another material that you requires four other resources, which you will need to make in abundance. When mining for metals, you *have* to go into caves, which immediately debuffs the player's stamina, but then you also run the risk of catching pneumonia, which further debuffs your stamina, and can leave the player with so little energy you might not even be able to jump or swing your pickaxe. This punishes the player twice over, for doing something that is required. (And makes no sense as you are hooked up to an 02 tank, not breathing cave air. Dying has the most severe punishments, though. Not only do you drop all of your belongings, (and respawn somewhere "randomly" if you didn't make a bed), but you also lose *all* of your progress to the next level, unless you can get revived by another player. And running is the only mode of transportation, so if you died somewhere far off, you could be running back to your corpse for upwards of 15-20 minutes. 

Tl;dr game requires far too much time and effort for underwhelming rewards and is extremely punishing.

Game needs a full re-balance.  Survival and crafting elements are fun but it gets to a point that all your time is spent to running to get more finite resources to craft yet more work benches. I think they want to make it feel like there is a struggle to survive, but they did that by adding more monotony instead of making bigger challenges to overcome at higher levels.  

Final issue is the countdown that keeps running if you aren't playing.  I'm fine with things resetting between missions.  Early game in survival is my favorite part, but just make the time shorter and have it count down while playing. If you can't make this game your highest priority, you will be punished for it by losing all progress and your character.

152942084.review:
Disclaimer: Played during a free weekend.

Icarus is a relatively polished and broad co-operative Open World Survival game and whilst it doesn't bring anything new of note to the genre it covers all the usual things you have come to expect and does so very well. The upgrade path is easy to grasp and progress along it it is well paced with a sufficient variety of resources.

The build system is a little limited for the moment and does not yet include any curved pieces or even angled flooring but does support complex, functionally useful and visually appealing if somewhat restrictively boxy structures. Decorations are well thought out and allow a reasonable degree of freedom in placement. To put it simply I could never build exactly what I wanted but I was also never displeased with what I could build and most importantly I rarely felt like I was fighting against the build system. Hopefully we will see an upgrade to add snap points to half pieces and the addition of equilateral triangles at some point in the development cycle.

Enemy variety is slightly better than the norm for these types of games, we will always want more but there is enough that you don't always feel like you are in the same fight at least. Some effort has been made to vary enemy tactics with the addition of predictable attack patterns for certain enemy types allowing you to sometimes learn and develop useful strategies but beyond that it is the standard 'passive enemies mindlessly run away and aggressive enemies mindlessly chase you down' fare that we are all familiar with. There is unfortunately no complex behaviour either scripted or adaptive to make things more interesting. I also did not witness any inter creature behavioural relationships beyond a few rare occasions of what may have been some creature running away from another. This is definitely a part of the game that is noticeably lacking; Even some very simple Predator, Competitor, Prey relationships would go a long way toward making the world seem far more alive.

Character advancement is both broad and deep, all skills are broken down to serve all of the specific wants and needs you may have allowing you to build into whatever role you most enjoy playing. You can also respec your characters Talents for a small cost to adjust to specific scenarios. Unfortunately you cannot do the same with your Tech Tree, leaving you with many wasted points in Tech as you progress through the levels and there are not enough points available in the standard game to learn everything; This ultimately restricts your characters longterm viability as it is entirely possible through a few mis-assigned points to lock that character out of certain content permanently.

Character adaptability to the environment is handled primarily through crafting. The game will throw many variations of hazards at you whilst opening up the ability to craft preventative and or curative items to deal with them. This system also extends into situational buffs such as increased melee damage or carrying ability etc in a way that allows you to boost your off abilities as necessary. This system is well fleshed out however I found that by the time I unlocked the recipes, crafting stations to make them and then gathered the necessary ingredients I had essentially moved beyond needing to use them. I feel this system would be better utilised if current consumables were moved down the tech tree and significantly more powerful ones added to the higher tech levels to make those buffs available when you actually need them and warrant continued use as you progress.

The game does include a taming system and the ability to use tamed creatures as mounts or even pack animals. This is a nice touch but, given the aggression of most of the creatures towards your mount when you are not around, is a feature you will likely ignore more and more as you progress. The extra speed/carry boost just isn't worth the hassle of constantly baby sitting your pet that will be targeted and killed by random creatures spawning on top of it the moment you are out of hearing range of it. There are Talents you can take to somewhat reduce the chance of aggressive creatures attacking your mount but not to any useful degree. Inter creature behavioural relationships would again be beneficial here as would expanding pet commands beyond follow, stay, or fight; The addition of a flee and some sort of return whistle or even just a flee to me when in danger command would help a lot.

Questing exists in the game, though in a very limited form; This appears to be expanded in the DLC but I have not had a chance to try that yet. Mostly in the base game it is of the go here and either kill x amount of y creature or defend this area for x minutes/waves. It gives you something to do when you are feeling kind of aimless which is always appreciated but it fails to give any reason to do it beyond a rather disappointing drop of reward items you probably have no use for. This is a failing most games in the genre suffer from and this game differs only in how very easy it would be to correct. The framework is all there to provide a reason for the players actions in their sojourns from an orbital station onto this terra-formed world to identify and test the environment and it's resources. It would be a simple matter to present this story to the player, include key milestones to work toward that advance the story and even add an ultimate conclusion that serves as both meaning to play and satisfactory resolution of play. It doesn't need a hoard of dramatic characters and deep themes with surprise twists, a story treatment would be enough; But it does need something to make this feel like more than a just a game framework or very large tech demo.

Multiplayer worked perfectly for me, it was easy for my friend to join and we had no random disconnects. Actions in game synced cleanly and having a co-op partner greatly added to the experience. Everything else the game has to offer such as Graphics, Movement, Sound etc are all of high quality and for me the game ran smoothly and without any major issues.

All in all if I was judging this game against all of the very many others in the genre I would give it a thumbs up, I certainly enjoyed my experience, were it not for the issue of price.

There is no polite way to put this so I will be blunt, the price tag of this game is delusional. This is a 25-30 USD early access indie game that they are trying to charge $120 USD for with every indication that they will continue to charge even more for each and every future update; The justification for this seems to be to pretend that the game is no longer in early access and that the ongoing patches to the game are expansions and not the very necessary feature updates they clearly are. I can only imagine this is a result of an inexperienced Chief Financial Officer who simply does not understand how to price a product in the PC Gaming market.

Whilst I certainly understand the need to ensure everyone gets paid and the desire to make a profit off of your product what the CFO seems to fail to understand is the higher you price your product the more you narrow your potential market. This game is actually priced all but entirely out of the PC gaming market, you could purchase two brand new AAA games for the same price they are trying to charge for this feature incomplete early access indie game. Even if by some bizarre series of events this game managed to capture the attention and wallets of all the 'whales' in PC gaming that fraction of a percentage of the market would be insufficient to cover the cost of development. By closing their product off to the average consumer this game is all but guaranteed to fail financially.

At $30 for the complete game this would be a clear winner for my co-op group and you would have had six more sales, at $120 it is a complete joke and you have nothing; Even RocketWerkz's CFO should be able to understand that math.

/////////////// 2023 June 29th ///////////////
[h1][b]Alright boi's, it's been a year, and so many people are saying theres SO MUCH IMPROVEMENTS, let's see what really changed.[/b][/h1]

What has changed since:
1. Open world mode: Short explanation = outpost mode + enemies + mission board loop system.
In order to start off the mission board system, you have to finish your character grind, so it's kind of an end game content.
You establish a permernant base, make your mission board, and start looping 8 difference types of missions, like gather / hunt / recon / blah blah.
Lore-wise it's more reasonable as well, you come down the planet, establish a front, stay on surface, and deliver the needs to space.

2. Progress wipe, so what really changed? That they need a progress wipe for it?
2a. Tech trees are literally the same, with some extra new contents, but it doesn't differ.
2b. Talents are literally the same.
2c. Workshops are literally the same, with some extra new contents, but it doesn't differ, I do not feel like re-doing all the grind just to test if small things are stackable or not.
2d. Missions, does the constructions stay? No.
So sum of point 2: Progress wipe, was it necessary, no, they just felt like disgusting you.

3. Repair bench, yeah, you no longer need to carry all the tables around, just one table.
4. Fishing features, some might like it.
5. Buffalo carts, +1000kg weight, -40 speed, probably good for hoarders moving bases, likely never going to be used.
6. Electronics: the material amount is the same, but they made it to gold wires + copper wires + electronics, no improvement, double the annoyance. 
7. Ammo: An extra process of making ammo casing, which has absolute no other uses other than making ammo, shotgun buckshots still costs the same, what an improvement.

[strike]I DO NOT UNDERSTAND WHAT HAS BEEN IMPROVED.[/strike] So, I guess the big gamer is the open world mode.

You could give them a thumbs up for that, for those that hardly played the game, they didn't lose much, for those that played hundred of hours, I don't really know.
You could argue that in open world mode, you will eventually finish the material grind, and since you're staying there forever, there's no more grinds after that, so just SUCK IT UP AND COPE IT.
So, did devs take feedbacks afterall? Or was it always their way or the highway?

You had a (insert_number_here) year relationship with Icarus, Icarus is good looking, at start you were "We've just got together, maybe there's more to Icarus, let's know Icarus more before judging", but then as time moves on, you've finalized that Icarus' personality was just too much to cope with.
A year later, Icarus' friends started to contact you, telling you that Icarus has changed a lot, Icarus is no longer the past Icarus that you know, you two should get back together.
So, you took your courage, and met up with Icarus, the first words spoken was "Hi, I've threw away everything that you worked so hard on to obtain, but I really need a new kitchen, and fridge, and a few new closets, it'll be good to put a furnace here, the roof needs a fix, better be weather-proof, you'll still need to go out and dig gold for 3 hours though, phone me when you're done."
That's ... what you'll face when you come back, Open World Mode might be good, but.

And there's another you know that had the same vibe but different ethnic, you knew NoManSky from a dating app, wasn't pretty, and nothing much to say about, never got together in the first place, but from time to time NoManSky comes back, not asking you for anything, but trying to prove itself to you.
2 years later, you two were together, you thought that was the end to the story, but NoManSky remembered every anniversary, and made it better after better.

It is hard to judge, maybe Icarus just needs more time, maybe another year.

152638519.review:
The game itself is actually quite decent. I'd even suggest picking it up during a sale and giving it a try. However, what really stands out in this situation is the fanservice and the way the developers handle their promises and criticisms.

Lately, on their official Discord, it seems like all they do is talk about the expenses they're dealing with to make everything happen. Frankly, it gets a bit tiresome hearing about these complaints. They only seem to be active when they're about to release something new, like New Frontiers now. Other than that, they can go for months without any communication. They're going on about how much effort and money goes into creating a pet in the game, costing anywhere from $30k to $50k, and how players don't really understand the work behind it. Then they talk about features like full mod support, which we all know breathe life into games (remember how DayZ did it?), and they claim it would cost millions. They also mention something as simple as character customization being worth a million dollars.

"Rocket | CEO" mentioned that those who bought the Supporters Edition will eventually get a significant discount. Depending on how many units are sold, the Supporters Edition might even end up not costing the developers anything, or possibly even causing them to lose money, especially in certain regions.

Honestly, this kind of messaging to the people who believed in them and invested more to receive what was promised is a bit surprising. It's common knowledge that pre-orders and early supporters often get better deals. It's not rocket science (no pun intended). It seems like they're trying to make it look like they're the ones carrying the financial burden, which doesn't really sit right. This is a standard practice, and usually, it's the other way around – pre-orders are given at a discount.

I can already imagine the defenders who will argue that we should support the developers. It's fine to have differing opinions, but we need to be honest about our concerns.

The financial equation here is quite simple. The Icarus Deluxe Edition (that was the name of the edition I bought) costs $109.98, yet Styx, which everyone owning the game received for free, has a standalone cost of $23.44 (on promotion). The first DLC, priced at $25.49, brings the total to $48.93. Even if we factor in the $8.99 for Styx and a $5.99 add-on with lamps (which is also part of the deluxe edition), the total comes to $63.91 - and the next DLC won't cost $40 for sure, does that mean they'll start slicing out every little feature and selling them for $3-4 each just to hit that price point?

The lack of transparency in their communication is baffling. Any expression of dissatisfaction is met with backlash from their supporters, who don't seem to grasp that if you don't voice your concerns, you won't see any improvements. On Discord, you're flooded with messages about how everything is perfect and fantastic, which doesn't make sense for a game that's still in development (and it's supposed to be the first year in Early Access, but that's a whole other issue).

Encountering yet another update that introduces redundant features like two shields, coupled with the ongoing lack of progress in the development of the station shop and the repeatedly emphasized but elusive focus on future improvements, has thoroughly exhausted my patience. The absence of effective communication on these matters has significantly eroded my enthusiasm. I'm left in a state of uncertainty regarding the specifics of what the next game update will bring: what content will be added and how the game will evolve. The broad statements provided often fail to align with the actual changes that emerge when an update is eventually released.

Take a look at the sudden surge in positive reviews today – it's clearly orchestrated by them.

I'm sharing this negative feedback not because I dislike the game itself, but because I'm disappointed in the way the developers are handling their communication and game development. I'd still recommend buying and playing the game. While it's notably under-optimized, the recent changes seem to make the gameplay more accessible for a wider audience. Whether it suits your tastes or not is something you'll have to decide for yourself. If they follow through with the DLC as promised, it could potentially breathe new life into the game.

105333403.review:
How's it going everyone?

I'm going to divide this into two parts: the pros and cons & tips for beginners. I feel like some people might get lost in the early hours of this game and I wanted to pitch my two cents worth of knowledge.

Pros:

- Fluid Day and Night Cycle.
- Dynamic Weather System.
- Temp/Food/Water/Oxygen Management.
- Extensive Talent Tree.

Cons:

- A Few Bugs on Release.
- Difficult to Find Fallen Loot and Objective Locations.
- Combination of Certain Elements Makes Gameplay Difficult.

Tips:

- Always carry x2 floors and x4 walls to build a temp shelter to protect you from storms.
- Always carry 1x bedroll if you need to place down an emergency spawn point.
- Always carry 30x Oxite so you don't run out of oxygen. 
- Set up camp near sources of water.
- Invest in bone weapons and medical equipment as soon as you can.

Hopefully this will help some of you in the opening days of playing the game. Let me know if you found this review helpful and offer any other tips I might have missed.

Have a Good One!

Let me preface this by saying by saying if you enjoy survival craft games, then you will most likely enjoy this game, despite the bugs and balance issues. 

TL/DR:
If game released AS AN EARLY ACCESS GAME - 8/10. 
Game released as a FULL RELEASE - 4/10

While I actually do recommend the game, I am giving it a thumbs down, because it is plain as day that this should not have been released as "full game"
IDK who had that bright idea, but you definitely dropped the ball on that one coach. 

This game is definitely fun, there are just too many bugs that are beta bugs, and the game is very poorly balanced and optimized. 

[b][u] BALANCE ISSUES [/b] [/u]
[list]
    [*]The level above the animals basically don't mean anything. I can one shot a lvl99 cougar with a stone arrow, but get 
        straight demolished by a lvl5 wolf after he takes 7 bone arrows to the face.  

    [*]Bears are absolutely over-powered. Unless there are 4 of you, or you use one of the many glitches to cheese them, good 
        luck. 

    [*]The XP penalty seriously needs to be reworked. I mean, it is horrendous. 
        [*] It's always the same; if you die, it resets your XP for the current level all the back to beginning. It doesn't matter if you JUST leveled up, or you are ABOUT to level up, and you better hope it's the former otherwise you basically have to  level up twice just to work off the debt. 
        [*]Tip to the devs - it should probably be a percentage of total XP earned for you current level. 

    [*] You do not get anywhere near enough Talent or Tech points to experience everything, ESP if you are a solo player
          [*]I'm not sure if there is a level cap, but during the beta I believe it was level 30. I'm level 23, and I'm super worried about whether or not I'm going to have to make a second character just to experience any of the tier 4 stuff. 

    [*] The cave worms seem broken; you can very clearly dodge their poison attack, but you somehow still get hit. IDK how their  coded, but it seems broken. 
[/list]


[b][u] BUGS/OPTIMIZATION [/b] [/u]

[list]
    [*] The recommended GPU is a RTX 3060 TI, which is just......what??
EDIT: apparently this is pretty standard for a lot of newer games. I guess I'm still getting used to idea that 30 series seems so unobtainable at non-scalper prices. 

    [*]The minimum RAM is 16GB, which again is just....what???

    [*] You will  constantly teleport to the very end of caves, and take massive amounts of damage and break every bone in your 
         body. Good luck killing the broken Caveworms then.

105326787.developer_response:
Hey Tutturu, thanks for the feedback, we really appreciate it.

As you've found, depsite our 3 months of Beta testing with the community there are still bugs for some players.

Balance issues:

We are always improving the animal AI and levelling system, we are aware it isn't perfect, but here are some tips:

 - Icarus is not a run and gun, using the sneak feature and aiming for critical hits to the head hitbox is extremely important, especially if you are playing solo.

- The XP debt is a lot, and we are always aware of what we need to balance more, but it's meant to be quite high otherwise there wouldn't be as much risk to exploring too far away from the safer zones etc.

- The solo talent tree helps a lot with this, but tech points may require further balancing, nothing is off the cards right now.

- The current level cap is 60, with Tier 4 unlocking @ level 30.

- We are aware of the sand worm issuse and they are currently being worked on.

Optimization:

- The recommended hardware is to play the game on High, not minimum.
We have seperate Minimum requirements to play the game at lower settings.

- We are aware of issues with trees, dropping items (sometimes they may just be under foliage, be careful) and teleport/flying bugs, all of the above are being worked on by our team as we speak.

- We are aware of clipping issues with some weapons, especially after you get knocked down or respawn, this is being fixed right now too.

Once again, we really appreciate people like you making specific lists like this, and rest assured we will attend to all of these ASAP.

The best way to submit feedback is to post it on our Feature Upvote page: https://icarus.featureupvote.com/

There are also specific methods for fighting animals and other tips our community have found here: https://steamcommunity.com/app/1149460/guides/

Thanks again, and we hope you return to enjoy more Icarus soon.

Cheers - Beinn

When I remembered that Icarus had recently launched, after the new Battlefield launch was completely ripped to shreds, I was really looking for something new to sink my teeth into and I wanted it to be Icarus more than anything. I expected quite a bit more content after playing through the first two missions, and maybe its only me, but I felt like the only 'new' content I saw from the Beta was different flora scattered around the world. Hey! Totally hear your concerns and opinions about the state of game development. However, I wanted to speak a little bit to Icarus and maybe give you some insight into the journey. 

Our approach to the game is definitely not one of lining the pockets or hiding everything behind micro-transactions, in fact, we're unlikely to have any micro-transactions for quite a while as our focus is purely on the core game and delivering consistent, regular updates to improve performance, bugs and add fresh content. 

Your concerns about the grey area between Early Access and Full Release are absolutely heard! We do believe Icarus is at a 1.0 state, but plan on regularly and actively improving the game, as bugs, bad performance and other hiccups are not intentional, and something we don't ruining your experience. We've already pushed out 2 hotfixes, and have many more to come, including one very soon. 

Obviously, launching the game with 0 bugs or misbalances is the dream, but also pretty hard to pull off! If you keep the faith in us, we'll be working to reward it. This project is the dream for many of us, we're not going anywhere!

109005867.review:
Don't get this game if you are a solo player. This game has been designed around everything being done in a group.

Main issues as a solo player: 
* This game was not designed for you in any way shape or form, in fact it actively tries to do everything in it's power to discourage you.
* This game does not respect your time.
* I've never seen a game so desperate for you to do nothing. Storm, go inside, do nothing. In a cave, have a debuff, it gets cold have another debuff, get a disease which is another debuff, now do nothing, your stamina is zero.
* Mining, this is a mining simulator for 90% of your time. It's annoying and boring. 

Probably the three most glaring examples of just how little the designers care about solo players.
* As a solo player when you die, you must wait for the re-spawn button to appear (15 seconds). Then you must hold down the key for an equal amount of time. Then you must click yes. Nobody else is playing, so nobody else can help you revive. There is literally no other options, so why not revive you back at your spawn point.
* The XP penalty, is an absolute dumpster fire of an idea. The death loop for solo players:
   - As above, jump through some hoops.
   - You lose all XP you gained this level (1 point of next level, that's right start again).
   - You get a penalty for earning more XP until you clear the amount you previously had for this level.
   - You have no gear, it's on your corpse (mind you the developers wanted to remove all your gear, they actually thought that would be fun).
   - You need to run back to your corpse, the mobs generally just sit on top of your corpse. Enjoy the likely hood of multiple dead runs (my favourite is when a storm immediately starts).
* All missions are balanced the same regardless of the amount of people in the group. So as a solo player the mission is balanced as if it had at least 4 people. That means in same cases collecting 1000s of things. You will get the same reward as each member of a group; might take you 8 hours vs their 1 hour, great design.

Game Issues:
* Buggy, very, very buggy. They seem to be slowly fixing some of the game breaking ones, so maybe one day it will be a far more pleasant experience.
* Poor interface design. There are so many games in this genre that are just flat out better user experiences, rather than copying them, they tried to re-invent it and made it worse.
* Debuffs, they stack, to the point you can do nothing (your stamina will be set to zero).
* No respecing, you of course read the internet and knew exactly all the various things they had in the multiple trees, knew your play style for the game and how those talents would effect it. No? Too bad, pick once or make a new character. The game designers still posting about how it will be game breaking should the introduce it.
* Hugely limited mobs, and they often don't make sense and are poorly scaled. This also seems to be deliberate, so they can sell dlc/expansions.

But the thing that topped all this off, was the game loop. It gets boring really quickly, the loop:
* start with nothing
* build a shelter
* find the cave with as much iron as possible, this is where you spend a lot of time, so the above point about it being very boring, makes this loop so much worse.
* fix your shelter to avoid everything being destroyed.
* Get a gun
* begin mission (usually run a very long distance).
* run back to ship... do it all again.

What's nice about this game?
* pretty graphics
* interesting idea with the constant returning to the ship, creates the above loop, so it's interesting, it just didn't work
* Nice building ideas, different types of things, could clearly build some intersting things, just never really did as once the mission is done, they disappear. They also take a lot of resources, so you tend to build tiny boxes. Don't be fooled by the pretty pictures, most people made them in the outpost mode or the 30 day missions. 
* I like the amount of different things that can be built, I just never got near most of them, as they had no bearing on the mission, and required vast amount of resources.

I don't need your fancy ray-tracing d*ck-swinging graphics, I can traipse around Ark all day and it looks just fine. What I need is for your game to work and for it to be fun to play. You failed.

The session-based time limit focused missions seemed cool, in theory. But it takes you about an hour to come to the realization that there's no point to doing anything because in an arbitrary amount of time, your work will be erased. Or you'll finish your objectives in a fraction of a fraction of that time limit and need to move on to the next mission to progress. So, instead of creating a cool base, you end up just making a 4x4 hut and putting the essentials in there. You won't be around long enough to give a sh*t, trust me on that. And you sure can't take anything with you because there's a magical barrier surrounding the planet that deletes anything in your inventory when you leave. You can carry a shitload of gear and resources in your magical, inter-dimensional pocket when walking around, but, oh boy, your space pod can just...only carry so much, ya know? It's realistic!

So, you're feeling pissed about the "mechanics" of the main mode? Want a permanent base? They offer that. You get slapped on a tiny map, with no challenge. No predators. No real game-play. No serious weather to worry about either. You can gain XP doing stuff, which is about the only benefit you get from playing that mode. I can't confirm either, but it sure felt like your xp gains were lesser than in the normal mode. Half my play-time was in the perma mode and I made it to level 3. The other half of the time was in normal mode and I ended that at level 8, with 3 deaths that reset my xp gains. There's math there, I'm sure.

Now for the real rant. Let's talk about my favorite subject: Game logic. AKA, how and why do things work in your game.

If I can perma-base in one mode, then why do I have a death-timer in any other mode? What kills me? What keeps them from sending another drop-pod down for you? They sure do that when you actually die and respawn. Are you just assuming that after exactly 6 days, 3 hours and 42 minutes, that part of the planet...explodes? I wouldn't make a big deal out of it, if the developers themselves didn't make it a *crucial* part of this game. So, I ask again, what kills you if you don't make the drop-pod timer? You won't starve, freeze, run out of oxygen. You have shelter. Tools. Weapons. It's not explained, despite being a fundamental aspect of the game. You miss the timer, you die. No reason. You can "die" a thousand times before that timer and here comes another drop-pod to respawn you tho. Or you wake up in bed. What? You get "left behind forever"? That's beyond stupid, beyond any logic. You can imagine the most nefarious corporation and even they wouldn't waste the time, money and resources to send carefully selected explorers across the galaxy to an alien planet only to leave them behind forever because they spent 7 days on the surface instead of 6...for no reason. "Whelp, Timmy didn't make the drop pod timer. Only cost us 8 million dollars to bring him here and we've only sent 834 drop pods down there already. He's a lost cause." Why even send these people to this planet and give them absolutely nothing in the way of tools or gear anyways? It would help if they took the time to  E X P L A I N. Which I (stupidly) assumed they would.

OH, and the time limit is in real-world time, which is just the most bizarre fourth-wall, immersion breaking idea ever. How the hell do you even...? How does that work in the game-world? Because the day/night cycle in game is *not* the same as the day/night cycle IRL. Imagine trying to journal that if you were your character. "Day 48. I landed on this strange planet with 6 days to achieve my goal. I have 3 days left. Only another 48 days before those 3 days are up. I ate oxygen rocks."

The time-space continuum shattering time-limit is not the only thing that breaks any illusion of immersion. You wear an evo-suit, yeah? Need oxygen, yeah? So...what happens when a wolf bites you? Does that not damage your suit? How are you casually eating barely cooked meat? Do you just rub it on your helmet and use your imagination? How do you drink water? Your suit doesn't protect you from any of the elements or temperatures? HOW DO YOU GET WET? How does it all work? This is important to me because it gets me in the f*cking MOOD to play. This isn't nit-picking. These are the questions that should be asked and I'm being serious. It's a survival game, this is what I'm here for. I'm here for it but when the mechanics they decided to implement don't make SENSE, I don't enjoy the experience. If I need to be in this stupid suit so you can peddle your "terraforming gone wrong" tagline, then make it apart of the god damn gameplay or don't f*cking do it!! Don't gloss over it so you can shove copy-paste survival mechanics in your game. 

Here is the perfect example: I walk into a cave, a weird worm creature pops out. (despite the world being specifically designed to support EARTH creatures BTW). This weird worm creature projectile vomits on me. I'm now poisoned and die. But...how? How does that work? Did you forget that I'm wearing an environmental protection suit? I sure have to worry about my oxygen bar but worm vomit just pops right through that suit and then into my bloodstream? It didn't damage my suit, mind you, my suit is indestructible. It never leaks, is never damaged. Always works perfectly fine, even when a bear is chewing on my torso. So, my suit is fully intact protecting me from the TOXIC atmosphere, but not from worm vomit? How did the poison get through the suit and into my bloodstream to then poison me and kill me? You think, dear non-existent reader, that I'm being ridiculous. But, I insist that it's questions like these that should have been asked WELL before a single developer touched a keyboard.

Yeah, I'm pissed. And a simple thumbs down is not enough to convey that.

At first times, it doesn't bother much but after you play for lots of hours and reach some level, it get so boring you can't imagine. And its not logical considering the story of the game.

Ok, since being a part of beta testing, I have a fair bit of time under my belt. And, after writing a dozen paragraphs for a review, I decided to delete it all and say this:
