110689996.review:
This game is a real gem.

I understand why it has mixed reviews, because a lot of people prefer survival games where you go on a map, make things, things respawn over and over and you can keep coming back.

Icarus is not that game.  However, I love that about it.

Icarus is a tough game, because as you level your points on your skill tree, you have to be keeping a build in mind.  Maybe guns are your thing so you level guns?  Maybe you're playing with friends and you want to be the gatherer so you put points into mining and weight, etc.  You only get so many points, so you have to keep in mind what build you want.  However, I quite like that about the game because it means that once you've reached the limit of that, how good you do will rely on you.

Crafting up to new tiers is rewarding.  It requires a lot of gathering, time, exploring, and keeping in mind what resources should be put into what.  The further out you go the more you'll get, but there's that mission timer to keep in mind.

You can, of course, make multiple characters, with multiple builds, and do different things.  So this balances if you level a character up the way you find doesn't work for you.  There is also a respec system now.

Then there's that beautiful piece about credits.  As you complete missions, you gain more credits, and eventually, exotics, in which case you can start buying things to bring down with you on missions, making things easier to deal with.  Instead of having to craft your way up to better picks, start with one.  Maybe you want armor.  Maybe an axe, etc.  This makes it easier over time as you go down to start well and get the ball rolling.

I'm not sure why some people are saying this "isn't a solo game", it is very much able to be solo'd, you just need to be prepared, and methodical in your approach to missions.  I've played the majority of my hours entirely solo minus maybe 2 or 3 missions with a few friends.  The thing to remember is that just because a mission is unlocked, doesn't mean that maybe your level is ready for it.  Don't be afraid to replay missions, don't be afraid to spend the extra time on that mission counter to level up, and don't rush the hard stuff.  The game clock on many missions is 7 real days, don't be afraid to use it all if you aren't sure if "you're prepared enough."  That said, it IS a difficult game, and it's meant to be.

The environment is very impressive.  I've heard rumors on the game that eventually there's bound to be MANY tiers of things to unlock, but for now, even the 4 is really fun.  You go from basically stone age huts to aluminum or concrete at some point if you want, and weapons are very similar.  Going from stone tools, to eventually very advanced composites.  The forests are thick, and can make hunting interesting.  You won't always see what's in the woods.  You might /hear/ a bear, you might /hear/ a wolf, but sometimes you end up face to face with one because you weren't paying attention.  Stealth plays a big part of that.  However, there's usually some kind of warning.  The audio effects are quite well done in hearing things off in the distance, what creature it is, and at least some form of, "Ok that is probably safe." or "I may need to tread carefully."

The mission progression is great, and doesn't just drop you in and go "LOL good luck."  Your first several missions are in relatively safe places to get your feet wet and learn the ropes, and then progresses from there.  Different biomes have different pros and cons.  You might find one where water is scarce, creatures are hard, but the caves and resources are plentiful.  Maybe an area has lots of wood and stone and trees, making base building easy, but you have to travel a ways for caves.  Of course, be careful with that torch if you're in the woods ;) you know?

If all of those things aren't all within consideration, keep in mind the weather on icarus also wants you dead, everywhere.  Lightning storms are a little scary, blizzards suck, sandstorms are wild, and sometimes animals just decide to complicate that in pack hunting.

This game hits nearly everything I absolutely love about survival games, with a new and interesting perspective on missions and drops, instead of a permanent spawn on a map.  This games the game interesting, challenging, with a great replay value to level up new characters, try new items, go hunt for exotics, play with your friends, explore new areas.  They did actually have outposts as well, for those who don't want a mission timer or objective, to be able to spawn in and just make things in a kicked back manner.

Now onto a few of the things I think could use some work:

Animal AI and pathing:  Sometimes the AI pathing is a bit odd.  It seems a little immersion breaking for an animal like a bear to be able to usually walk up what seems to be a nearly 90 degree cliff to come eat you.  As well, sometimes the "stealth" perception of the animals feels a little broken.  For instance, why is it an animal 100 meters out or so suddenly is spooked from me stealthing from the bushes onto a rock face when I can barely see it?  As well, sometimes stealthing in a house has this same effect, since I'm not in brush "cover" but I'm in a house, animals will "see me" even if I'm perfectly still.  Little weird.  I know the game just came out, so I'm sure this stuff is in the works, but I figured I'd mention it.  Also animals getting stuck attempting to go and jump on cliffs is pretty common in a few spots.

The pneumonia in caves is a bit weird.  Long as I'm in and out, and let that little red cave sign go away, I can go back in for a short time, go back out and the effect just resets so it never happens.  It's a little bit odd.  Even more odd that in very dry climates like the desert caves that it's as much of a concern.  Seems a little inconsistent but it's not terrible, just a bit of an "well, this is odd." mechanic.

Animal spawning:  It seems, from what I can tell so far, that animals seem to spawn in front of the character, as sometimes you can see them spawn in.  Not behind, it seems, just where you're looking, even if briefly.  Perhaps I am seeing it wrong, or misunderstanding.  The reason it seems to be this way is I noticed if I cross a biome, such as the snow, things like grizzly bears spawn in there till i'm /in/ the snow, and then polar bears spawn.  And sometimes the opposite.  It seems it'd make more sense to spawn things in an area, or based on biome within an area.  It's not a huge deal, just a small gripe.  

These are all relatively small things that are more "not sure why it does this, kinda don't like it, but not a game breaker" level.

If you love survival games, you want an interesting new take on a survival game, with a very very playable game out of the gate, with a dev team that is working their butts off on making improvements, with a promising road map, this game is absolutely worth the buy.

I realize I've now written a book, so, thanks for coming to my ted talk I guess.

105402867.review:
Here's the truth about this game.  5 Things you SHOULD know.

1) This is a coop game. It's not meant to be played solo. You can, but not only you will struggle more than what's acceptable to have fun, but you also won't be able to experience the entire game. 

Besides having to walk all the way back to your corpse and get a huge XP penalty - since you have no one to revive you, you won't be able to unlock all construction blueprints or even all talent points on MOST talent trees. I am not even talking about all talents in the game. Forcing you to start a new character again and again, until you find out what build works for your playstyle.

2) The game doesn't consist of an X-Number of missions. It consists of one mission. You just start a NEW GAME PLUS when you finish a mission. Let me explain. 

When you finish a mission and you leave the planet, everything there gets deleted. Your structures and crafted items. Trees and mining nodes get reset. After every mission, you start from scratch. You have to start with a stone axe again and again. And no you cannot take anything with you. Your crafted rifle that took you hours and hours from landing to craft, stays there*.

This is effectively a new game plus. Where you only keep your character's skills - like in most games. And that's assuming you make it to the dropship before the timer runs out. Or else your character gets wiped as well.  So to complete the game, you have to start a new game, again and again, making sure you remember to extract your character after each successful or failed mission.

*You can unlock items while not on a mission that you can take with you to the planet but these items require missions to get since you need the special currency. Oh and make sure you don't lose these items, or you have to do more missions to make enough money to re-purchase them. So don't wander too far and die alone.

3) Make no mistake, this is an early access game. Very few things were fixed during the "beta". And the game doesn't feel even remotely feature-complete for an 1.0 game. Don't give me the DLC crap.

There are like 3-7 different animals per biome. No insects, birds, reptiles. The pathfinding on these animals is mind-blowing. They get stuck at the smallest rocks, fallen trees or they just cannot get out of the water. They run or charge at you in a straight line. If you shoot an arrow at a wolf 200 meters away and you manage to hit it, it turns towards you and starts coming your way knowing exactly where you are.

The optimization is... Let's say the game runs the same as it did 3 months ago. And no. The visuals don't justify the extreme hardware requirements. It's like being forced to buy a powerful car just because the road only goes uphill.

Let's not even talk about bugs and requested features. Bears that spawn on top of mission objectives just to kill you, getting thrown above the clouds, and more. On https://icarus.featureupvote.com, you will find thousands of reported bugs and requested features that have not and will not make it into the game. 

4) Lack of story - lore, poor writing, and missing promised features. 

No introduction video. The game doesn't make the tiniest effort at giving you an idea of what is going on. You are supposed to be on a terraformed planet that has gone wrong, but there is nothing indicating that this isn't earth. Apart from 2-3 animals that don't exist on earth, everything else is familiar. They promised to add more alien-like biomes in later DLCs. Let me say that again... DLC!

There oxygen there is supposed to be poisonous for some reason. But that's just for you. The animals there can breathe just fine. Oh, and if you're wondering why you can catch pneumonia in caves while wearing your helmet, so do i.

The vehicle and space station gameplay you saw in the trailer was scrapped without warning. So did a few alien-looking creatures you saw. None made it into the game. If you don't follow their dev blogs and live streams, you may feel scammed and I don't blame you.

5) It has one of the most toxic communities. If you mention something in the forums that you don't like and wish it were different - as well as provide solid feedback and ideas, you are labeled a troll and told to refund and get the F out. 

There's no matchmaking so unless you have a friend who plays games and happens to like this one, you have to go on the forums and randomly start sending friend requests. 

__

There's a reason the reviews are mixed right now. If you really want to play this game, I'd suggest giving the devs a few more months to polish it. Maybe even wait for the DLCs to come out so the game can feel more like what you were first presented.

109772817.review:
This game makes me frustrated. It started off really fun. The early game is polished and there's a steady progression through the tech tree, but it quickly devolves into a grind fest. Missions all lean very hard on making you travel absurd distances to create an illusion of gameplay and the highest tier of the tech tree is an unabashed time waster that is for some reason required for some missions. This game is an early access title that pushed out a release well before it was ready both in terms of polish and content.

The missions in this game are designed to waste your time and pad out game time. All the missions require you to just move across the map. Most of the mission gameplay is traveling across the terrain or waiting for timers to finish. There's no real gameplay during these portions just running. Spending 15 minutes running between objective markers is not my idea of fun. What even is the point?

Even in the missions where you have to gather resources, they place the drop pods where you have to deposit the different resources incredibly far apart. So you have to run from one to the other in order to drop off your gathered resources. And then after you grind out the stuff they ask for, you have to make another long trip back to your drop pod to leave the mission.

Why pad out missions with so much travel? There is no real gameplay involved in moving from objective marker to objective marker. Food isn't an issue because wildlife is abundant. Water and oxygen are equally plentiful. The only thing you have to look out for are aggressive animals, but all the common ones die quite easily to bows from a distance or knife stabs to the head (1 to 2 hits to kill even in the late game) if they get close. The only potential threats are the big animals in each biome (bears in forest, elephants in desert, and polar bears in arctic), but they're not that interesting to fight since they just run at you. If you're by yourself, it's just a damage per second check: can you kill it before it kills you (if you have an iron knife, leather armor, and the cooked meat buff the answer is yes if you're mostly stabbing the head)? If you're with even one other person, the person being attacked can kite and dodge the animal until the other guy kills it.

The late game tech trees are a massive waste of time. to even craft the items you will need to strip mine many many caves of copper and gold. This is an absurd ask when caves aren't that common. You're once again running around. I would be okay with this because having an organic reason to travel like mining out all the resources around you is cool, but you need an absurd amount of resources to build any item that requires electronics.

Instead of creating an interesting tech tree and letting players explore the different items, the game uses massive resource requirements so a mission that just requires you to reach the final tech tree and build some items from it will have hours of time spent stuck at the previous tier slowly mining resources to build 5 items. Electronics cost way too much to be asking for 30 for each item.

If we stayed down on the planet longer, these massive requirements for higher tech items might make sense. Like if a mission was a series of different objectives and we ended up staying on the planet long enough for us to organically gather stuff and decide to tech up. But they can't do that because for some insane reason they decided to put a real world time limit on your missions. If you don't leave the planet before that time limit is up, YOU WILL LOSE YOUR CHARACTER. This means that longer term missions just won't work for people unless they increase that limit to the point where they might as well remove it or cut off an entire mission type from people who can't commit to playing this game multiple hours a night.

Overall, this game is fun for the first 12 hours or so when you're just exploring and figuring stuff out. As soon as you level past the early game, the game starts becoming tedious travel quests. There's no depth here, only time wasters smothering an interesting concept and decently executed core systems.

I'll keep playing this to hang out with friends, but I don't enjoy my time in the game.

105244515.review:
I'm seeing a lot of half hour playtimes refunding, which is understandable if they truly feel like that's enough time to get a feel for a game.
At the time of this review, I've played a solid two play sessions, a total of about 9 hours.
I didn't play the beta, for what it's worth.
Some of this was solo, some was coop with my brother.
So far, I have experienced none of the issues with stability or framerates that others have seen, though I am running a fairly above-average machine. I don't see any reason to stat dump to flex, but suffice to say it is more than enough to run this flawlessly thus far.
My survival game experience runs the entire list, really- From Rust to Ark to that god awful pirate Ark game and everything in between.
While I'd never say that Icarus reinvents the genre by any means, it certainly takes some of the best parts of my favorite survival games and puts them in one place. I like that.
Lots of gathering and crafting, more like Ark than most, but with less of a grind. Anyone who says that Ark isn't a grind either hasn't played it or has their xp and gathering at 10x.
Food and water/O2 requirements make you think tactically but aren't oppressive- I don't find myself needing to eat every two minutes to avoid starvation.
The various medical treatments you unlock (and will need) are enough to keep you collecting materials for the next time you get bitten by a wolf and end up with a blood disease, or drink water and get the old Oregon Trail Killer.
Just a bit ago I realized they'd even implemented a game tracking mechanic ala theHunt, where a wounded animal can be tracked by blood trail. Its the little things like that that make me happy.
My brother and I have been working on the second area missions, with the radars, and have been having a blast. Perhaps playing with people you enjoy being around isn't the most objective way to give a game a rating, but then this game DOES allow for my brother and I to drop in and out of the same world and play together while thousands of miles apart with zero issues with connection or ping, so.
The crafting tree is fairly large, the tech tree expansive enough to keep me going level by level, and while the base building isn't "permanent", since you're leaving the planet soon enough, on the next drop I have a bunch of new pieces and ideas for the new base- I see this only as a positive.
I would like to see more variation in fauna, though admittedly I haven't been very far in the map (which is enormous). Once you get a bow and figure out the aiming system you can drop wolves and other animals with ease from almost any range.
In all, I find myself enjoying the game, wanting to play more, and experiencing it all with friends- I'm not sure what else I could ask for.
The animal pathing could be better, with some animals getting stuck on rocks occasionally (though that has saved my life more than once, so perhaps I shouldn't complain.)
And now, unlike most of the reviews I see, I will leave my comments open so that I can be called a shill or whatever.
I paid full price for the game, including support edition (simply because I thought the game looked good, not because I was necessarily hyped beforehand), and see myself getting my money's worth.
Buy it, don't buy it- obviously that is entirely your prerogative, and this review shouldn't do much to persuade you... I would, however, recommend watching some gameplay on youtube or twitch rather than allowing the Steam reviews to point you in one direction or another.

128928394.review:
This game is not a hand-holding survival game. There isn't a tutorial, so it's best to be familiar with the basics of survival games (food, water, shelter) before tackling it. 

I love survival games, but I was unsure of the game in the first 30 minutes of the game. 

I chose to go open world before doing missions, because I thought that would let me get my feet wet with the basic mechanics of the game before trying timed missions. Bad idea! I got my feet wet alright! From running through a stream back to the location of my death numerous times. My level 1 self kept getting mowed down by a level 75 wolf. In fact, all the critters in the area were high level. The wooden spear was useless.

After 20 minutes of doing this, I decided to do the starter mission instead, hoping it was a little easier. It was. The starter mission needs to be completed in 7 days - I thought this meant in game days - no it means real world days, so I no longer felt burdened by the timer. Predators and critters were more my level. Note: Make a spear ASAP because there will be a wolf coming for you! 

I found the game a bit boring at first. Nothing to do but forage rocks and sticks - of course, that is pretty standard with most survival games. However once the levels started coming and I had points to invest in blueprints and talents, the game began to become more appealing. By the second hour, I was hooked.

Some of the highlights of my first few hours were:

- Accidentally killing my first deer by chopping down a tree. Yes, falling trees hurt! 

- Experiencing my first major storm and playing "whack a mole" with my repair hammer as the storm shredded my little thatched hut. Advice: Get to wood as soon as you can. During a storm, trees can fall on your hut causing lots of damage. 

- Killing a fish with a bow for the first time - it's pretty easy!

- Watching a tree get struck by lightning, causing it to catch fire - and then a major forest fire erupted.

Long story short (too late) - if you like non-hand-holding survival games, try this one out! Be warned though - this is a man versus nature game, not man versus man.

122925398.review:
[h1]TL:DR; Yet another survival game marred with moronic game design decisions.[/h1]

The fundamental problems with [i]Icarus[/i] are:

* It doesn't respect your time,
* It is buggy,
* It is unoptimized, and
* Has too many bone-headed design decisions which aren't fun.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
[i]Icarus[/i] uses Unreal Engine 4.  On a high end gaming PC the game looks beautiful.  Unfortunately, you pay a price for this quality.  There are numerous problems:

* Moving around exhibits constant micro-stuttering as it pages in the terrain geometry and textures.  I have a 24-Core/48-Thread Threadripper 3960X, 64 GB of RAM, a RTX 2080 Ti, and the game installed on a Hyper Quad M.2 RAID v2 with 4x Sabrent Rocket NVME drives.  It [i]constantly[/i] micro-stutters as you move from grid cell to grid cell. Happens in both single and multiplayer. There have been reports turning off animal health bars helps to minimize stuttering but sadly that did not for me.  Setting FOV to max is also reported to help (I haven't tried.)
* Shadows constantly flicker due to the shadow's algorithm implementation.  This may cause headaches.
* Worse, there is no option to turn shadows completely off, you are stuck with a Low setting.
* The game is too dark with no brightness / gamma setting.  Turning shadows to Low allows you to see in caves.
* Lighting is hideously incorrect.  Inside walls of a house will be lit up even though the sun is occluded!?!?

[h1]Audio[/h1]
While it doesn’t have [i]New World[/i] level of audio polish the audio quality is OK.  

The music tends to get repetitive.  [i]Satisfactory[/i] is an example where each track sounds fresh each time it is played.

[h1]UI[/h1]
Icarus continues to miss basic Quality-of-Life features.  For example, there is:

* No “Take All” key bind so you manually have to click the button every time you loot a corpse,
* No way to replay the last prospect with the same settings so you have manually click all the options every single time,
* No "use" hotkey to open your drop shop, and
* No  "use" hotkey to Return to Station.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The game is filled with bugs and bad game design decisions.  For example:

* Want to sleep at 7:01 am? Nope, can’t! WHY does the game need to [b]micromanage my time?[/b]
* Why do I NEED a campfire/fireplace close to my sleeping bag [b]to sleep indoors?[/b]
* Why does [b]no in-game time pass[/b] when I go to sleep and wake up the next day?  i.e. Ores don't smelt in the furnace, storms haven't progressed, etc.
* Why does the map always have a fog of war? We don't have the technology to [b]bring a paper map[/b] with us?!
* We can launch to/from space but we can't craft firearms or bullets in the space station to bring down with us? But we can bring a bow + arrows with us??
* Why can't my base survive between missions? A base not persisting on the surface I could MAYBE see with the excuse of surface storms (how do the wildlife and plants survive though?) but if my base is [i]built in a cave[/i] it should persist between missions.
* Who magically comes to [i]restock all the ores[/i] between prospects?
* Why can I carry 2,400 wood but I can't more then 1 extractor?
* Sticking an animal carcass in the skinning bench stops it from decaying. This bug has been around since Beta. Does QA even play the game? Do the devs even listen to QA?
* Why can’t I use a rock to kill a Scorpion??
* Why do animals not scuttle for covering during a storm?
* Why do [b]wolves and bears SIMULTANEOUSLY[/b] gang up against YOU even though they are [b]enemies in real life?[/b]
* Do you like chopping down a tree only to have it spontaneously fall on your head?  Then you will enjoy Icarus.
* Having a gamepad plugged in but using the mouse+keyboard will cause the popup tool tips to constantly flicker.
* There is no way to skip the annoying landing / take-off cutscene.
* The game is a P-I-G to load.  A prospect mission timer will count while you are [i]still in the landing[/i] cutscene! By the time landing is complete the mission timer will have already wasted 45 seconds.
* While you can sort your Loadout in the space station [b]any changes do not persist[/b] due to stupid auto-sorting. How do you screw up [i]basic inventory management [/i] in 2022???
* You can bring arrows down from the space station but the instant you use 1 arrow you can no longer bring the [i]remaining arrows[/i] back with you up to the space station!  Stop nickle-and-diming my gear.
* Certain missions have [i]horrible directions[/i] such as [i]Waterfall: Expedition[/i].  Be prepared to watch videos on YouTube to clarify what you are supposed to do.

Ignoring bugs the biggest problem is the bad design and incomplete features:

* It is TEDIOUS to have to keep rebuilding a base. EVERY. SINGLE. MISSION.
* The crafting costs for  Tier 3 and Tier 4 are too high. Most are them are a complete waste of time.  [b]NOTE:[/b] There ARE mods that fix this but players are left on their own to track them down.
* When you die you lose ALL your XP for that level.  [b]Stop STEALING my XP when I die![/b] [i]Diablo 2[/i] and [i]Path of Exile[/i] did this garbage decades ago and it gets real old real fast.
* Movement speed is too slow for how big the world is.  There are no vehicles in the game thus you are left playing [i]Walking Simulator 2000[/i].  I haven’t had a chance to try out the new mount update but allegedly the travel speed is not any better.
* The [i]Repair Bench[/i] has been "Coming Soon" since December.  It has been 9 months since the game has been out and the Tech. Tree is [i]still[/i] incomplete.  This is an [b]EARLY ACCESS game[/b], not a v1.0.
* Workshop has numerous nickle-and-dime items that are lateral “improvements” instead of [i]meaningful[/i] improvements.
* Level is soft-capped at 50 but there is no way to take [i]all[/i] the talent points in offline play, or at the very least, max out all the solo talent points (since you are only given 25 solo points out of 50.)  [i]Conan Exiles[/i] has a popular mod that increases the level cap from 60 to 300.  Icarus needs an option to allow the max level to be configured by the host.
* Why am I limited to 3 character slots?  What is this? A console game from the 1990s??
* If you abandon a mission via “Return to Station” you can NOT re-join it. Be careful if you leave your friend's game!
* Mission types lack variety.
* Playing in Outpost mode lacks missions.
* No official way to change your Output difficulty. There is in unofficial way to make another another outpost with the same name and delete your previous one but I haven't verified this.
* No way to rename your character.  Hope you didn't make any spelling mistakes!

[h1]Summary[/h1]
The game CAN be fun especially with friends.  Bugs are S-L-O-W-L-Y getting fixed:
* When the game launched you couldn’t sleep in a sleeping bag with a fireplace active. It HAD to be a campfire.
* Solo talents point are no longer shared with the multiplayer ones. 
* Extractors no longer take hours to babysit.
* There is a left slot and we can put a torch in it.
* There is finally the option to respec talent points – although [i]months[/i] after enough people complained about it.  
* You CAN finally keep leveling above level 50 continuing to get Blueprint points to max out Tech Tree.
Unfortunately, with all the bugs, and bad game design decisions, the game needs another year of polish before I would consider recommending it IMHO.

Summary: Not recommended, only on sale.
Final score: 2/5.

Edit: Fix grammar and spelling.

140738680.review:
[h1] BUY IT - I cannot praise this game enough [/h1]

[b] TL;DR: [/b] Icarus combines the best elements of so many Player vs Environment (PvE) games with strong support for multiplayer. There really is something in this game for everyone regardless of your play style and it's done [b] well. [/b] If you're on the fence about buying this game, trust me, buy it.

This is the first LONG review I've written; so it should be clear that I really love this game and think you will too.

[hr][/hr]

I'll break this review up into three sections:
1. Why You'll Love Icarus
2. Things that Could Be Better
3. Historical Context


[h1] Why You'll Love Icarus [/h1]

- [b] Wonderful multiplayer support: [/b] This is my groups GO TO game to play together

- [b] The game has something for everyone: [/b]
	- Building structures is easy and flexible (see the Could Be Better for some hints)
	- Cooking (Food buffs)
	- Hunting (character trait bonuses and stealth add bonuses)
	- Mining 
	- Crafting (Tech tree has so many tiers of items you can learn to unlock)
	- Farming (lots of vegetables you can grow and gather in the wild)
	- Mounts (Dinosaur Chicken and Buffalos you can ride or use as pack animals)
	- Exploration (the map is HUGE)
	- Boss fights
	- Fishing (new)
	
- [b] Icarus does the basics WELL: [/b] You can tell the devs poured a lot of time into making the basic, repetitive tasks (chopping trees, mining, hunting) enjoyable and run smoothly. It makes the game very enjoyable.

- [b] 3rd Person view: [/b] Honestly this doesn't get enough wrap. If you're a person that suffers from motion sickness and 1st person view makes you nauseous, then Icarus's 3rd person mode (default: press "c") has got you covered. It's well done and you can do everything you can do in 1st person.

- [b] Traits: [/b] The trait system (bonuses that your character can unlock) add wonderful flavor and customization to your character. Want to focus more on hunting? Put more of your trait points in to the hunting tree. Mining? Put them in the mining tree. There are like 12 different traits trees that you can mix and match. As you level-up you get more traits points you can spend. Love it.

- [b] Constant Updates: [/b] The devs have been updating the game weekly since launch. As of the writing of this post, we are in the 80-something weekly updates. Most of the neg reviews you see are people who were upset about the way the devs handled character migration. I came in after that update so I cannot speak to that. However; I can tell you that almost all of the updates I've experienced have been net positive improvement. 


[h1] Could Be Better [/h1]
These are things I think could be better. And [i] even [/i] with these, I still [i] 100% [/i] would recommend that you buy this game.

- [b] Newbie understanding of tech tree: [/b] This has been improved a bit in the last update that revamped the tech tree. Starting out as a newbie it was very difficult to understand how different tech tree items related to each other. So you'd end up spending your tech points on 3-out-of-4 of the items you needed and would then have to wait to level up to get more tech points. Items dependencies aren't clearly articulated.

- [b] Injuries: [/b] Injuries in the game (a negative buff on your character) feel a little flat. I would encourage the devs to make them feel more real. A good example of how to do it well would be Green Hell.

- Honestly, that's all I can really think of. There are bugs here and there but I've seen SO many bugs get fixed each update thanks to the built in reporting tool. Seriously. Just get the game.


[h1] Historical Context [/h1]

When I was looking to get this game, I saw the "Mixed" for All Reviews and I thought, "ehhhhhhhh, IDK if I want to spend money on it." I bought it and bought a copy for a friend. I tried it out and died by a bear within the first 10 minutes. I closed the game and thought, "what a bust." But wait, you say, I thought you love this game (I do).

Thankfully, my friend tried it out and convinced me to give it another go. We've played Valheim, Green Hell, Satisfactory, Space Engineers, Terraria, you name it. So when he said, "Woah, I think this one might be the best thus far" I had to give it another shot. [b] GLAD. I. DID. [/b]

Icarus combines so many of the elements that make each of those games great, and it does it well.

When the game first launched it was rough (hence the mixed reviews), but the developers kept iterating, kept improving, kept fixing bugs, and adding meaningful content. You can tell this game is a labour of love for them.

People will always be mad about change. And the ones most upset will be the most vocal. 

I love this game. My friends love this game. I think you'll love this game. 

So what are you waiting for? Just get it and try it out. (or watch some let's play on youtube).

121365018.review:
TLDR: Missions are too long, doing anything of use is unengaging while also taking too long and EVERYTHING feels unrewarding including perks, mission rewards, shop equipment and anything else.

I will break this into two sections, in the first i will explain the problems the game has in order to inform those may seek to purchase the game, in the second i will offer possible solutions with multiple options that would be better suited to the game as a whole in an effort to aid the developers and perhaps offer ideas for the community to rally behind or suggest themselves.

First and foremost however i will begin by stating that i do not believe the game needs to make structures permanent and i firmly believe that doing so would altar the identity of the game and its premise so drastically that it may as well be a different game entirely.
What i do believe however is that they need to change things and fast, regardless of it "breaking" balance as the balance is already non-existent and the game ultimately stands pointless and purposeless and i do not mean that it lacks story or narrative, i mean there is no reason to progress and no meaningful progress to be made even if there were. It is, by every definition of the words, Not Fun.

1. Problems: there are two ways to do this type of game correctly which is to either make things easy and cheap to get and use however you have to remake them frequently meaning every mission, or make them expensive and time consuming to get yet make them meaningful by allowing you to keep them either for good or requiring occasional maintenance to continue working. As it currently stands Icarus falls into a midpoint where it harnesses the worst of both ideas- it can take hours of only running from one cave to the next just to find the materials required, possibly several more hours to harvest enough then haul it back to base, takes possibly several hours more for them to process so you can use them for said item and all of this after you spend several more hours building a home and the required benches with which to build other benches which you will need to make the station for refining materials for the item as well as the item itself, Then when you are done with just that one singular mission that you will have to do a dozen more of to earn the slightest of permanent rewards,, you leave the planet and all that work is wiped away, you realize that you just threw away an entire day of your life to complete one single mission and the second you hit "begin prospect" again you will have to start all over from square one.

the lesson is that when something is easily gained, you do not mind loosing it.
when something is hard fought and you lose it, you feel cheated.

once on the station you have The Store, i am glad to say that for once it is not a premium store, instead you can use points you earn after each mission to buy items you can take with you on your next mission and make life easier for you, you would think this would make the pain of saying goodbye to your hard work worthwhile correct? sadly not, nothing here makes a large enough impact and ultimately once you get your preferred setup you just go "ok what now?" because you will face mostly the same challenges over and over again and the items do very little besides "+%25 more gold harvest" or "+%30 more leather from animals". you will not get to a point where you say " i need to bring heavy fur instead of battle armor because its in the snow" instead you will bring your battle armor, make a house and workbench and use your armor to kill animals then make fur armor and head off on your mission with both suits in tow. you will not get a point where you say "i wont bother bringing the pick this time because my friend is the builder" you will bring it anyway because its best if you can split up to gather resources.

I have to ask the developers: how do you think people will find this fun?, why do you think people will want to play this game this way? why would they play this above other games of similar style or genre? because your special?, your not. and i do not mean that in a disrespectful way, it is a simple truth that nobody in any industry is special when there are competitors in said industry.

2. Solutions: bellow is a a list of things that could be implemented that would resolve issues within Icarus.
Resources: cut the costs of everything on tier 3 and 4 by %50, no questions asked, especially electronics, it makes no difference if you increase their spawns or their yield from each node if i end up sitting in my base for more than 45 minutes watching videos on my phone just to keep the process going. dont like that idea? introduce a minigame where you need to pay attention to the smelter or build components yourself and if you do a good job you get bonus materials, give me a reason to pay attention by rewarding me with less crafting time if i do, however it needs to be significant or it will make no difference, %10-20 bonus will not be enough.
The Store: Allow us to purchase miniature crafting stations from the store with research points, allow us to pack it up and take it back with us as well. the idea of having to progress through crafting bench>furnace>anvil>masonry bench before you can make stone is nice at first but after a few missions it gets tedious and tiresome, allowing us to use our points to skip a few steps gives meaningful progression and a good use of our points while also promoting group play and diversity of playstyle, allowing each player to contribute in a more meaningful way. i would suggest a basic anvil, mini-masonry bench, portable forges, collapsible cement mixer, ammo press, cooking pot, maybe even a small portable generator that cant be used for much but takes less fuel and can be used immediately. aside from just crafting stations let us bring firearms as well, perhaps a high caliber single-shot break action which takes ammo you can only buy from the store, something that you want to keep for emergencies and nothing else, or a flare gun that scares away wildlife and it wont come back. let us have a very expensive buggy that has good carry capacity, can be damaged by wildlife, requires fuel and clearing pathways to use well, not enough? make it take up to 3 slots to bring with you on a drop, want fuel? takes an extra slot so your group could end up with a dedicated driver.
The environment: The game was sold on aliens, there are no aliens. yes they are coming in the DLC, no that has not made it better. you dont need to go all out before the DLC but give us a better taste or you wont have people to buy the DLC.
The Missions: Allow us to select different drop spots that actually matter and offer different obstacles to start with, start in the desert?-better bring a canteen or find water fast. Start in the riverlands?-better bring ammo its bear turf. different areas can be closer to the objective but more hazardous, making ones preparation, gear and experience matter more. currently this is not the case.
Permanence: perhaps instead of allowing everything to be permanent, allow us to bury a supply cache we can recover and if we dont it gets lost, perhaps we could unlock a transmitter to turn in, get paid for and accept new missions before we leave our established foothold, making the idea of getting out on time a greater peril to keep track of.

There are many ideas that could quite easily save this struggling title, however as it stands there is simply no reason to play it. who wants to spend hours to build something just to see it destroyed? who wants to spend hours, days even to unlock something that will ultimately not feel much different than before? who wants to buy into a game just to see its whole identity shift away from why you bought it? and why will it matter what it becomes if nobody is around to see it?

145032015.review:
Icarus is a game undermined by its unusual design choices and poor balancing.

It’s a survival/crafting game, but rather than giving you a persistent world, in the "main game mode" you are repeatedly sent down with everything except your skill progression and tool unlocks reset.

In typical survival game fashion, making items requires a bunch of prerequisite materials. You pick up sticks and rocks to make stuff to acquire better materials to make better stuff to acquire better materials.

But those tools also require unlocking a progression tree with skill points. And almost all items require one of many special benches to make, and the benches themselves require unlocking and materials.

As is often the case with these games, some items have a chain of items and builds that borders on the ridiculous, for what can feel like minimal improvements.

Icarus is also mission-based, so you get thrown down to the planet with nothing, start from scratch every time, and can take nothing back with you.

This means every time you start, you’re almost certainly going to spend your first 15-30 minutes doing the same things – picking up sticks, rocks, and chopping down trees to make the basic things you need to survive.

The missions have timers. Originally, these were real-world timers that ran even when you weren’t playing the game. Start a mission with a 24 hour limit, and if you didn’t complete it within 24 hours of real time, you failed. Fortunately, the devs realized this was an unpopular design path and switched it to being “in game time” only. But this has the effect of making the current time limits a non-issue.

Most of the time the tension seems to be “how much grind do I want to do before I start the actual mission goal?”

Icarus understands that the “scrabbling to survive” part of survival games is often the most fun, but making you replay exactly that every time on every level and every mission gets old quick. There are no real shortcuts to get past this repetitive start, either.

Unlike some other games (Valheim, for example), there are no ruins to discover, no items to find, no treasures to seek. You’re in nature, up against regular animals. There aren’t many types in each biome (and it’s the standard forest/desert/snow, too).

The combat is not great. Even at a high level, if the wrong kind of animal gets the drop on you, you are probably going to die, and probably with your inventory or loot windows open as you frantically try to close them. Combat is mostly sniping from far away, hoping for a stealth kill, and then running like hell or exploiting terrain.

If more than one creature is aggroed, you’re also probably going to die. Even at Level 50, I am carefully sneaking around and completing many missions by running and hiding, rather than doing things “properly”.

Combat tends to be either trivial, or “oh, fuck this”.

There is a punitive death penalty when you do die. Plus you have to run back to your corpse to get your hard-earned hand-built stuff.

You can build elaborate bases, but given the inherently disposable nature of them in missions, you’re going to build the smallest possible thing, usually out of wood, since any of the other materials require a grind completely not worth the benefits for a specific mission. This is also the problem with most of the upper tier objects – the benefits don’t seem worth the grind.

Even if you build a nice base, a storm might blow it (and the benches inside) to bits, or lightning might set it on fire and burn it to the ground while you are on the other side of the map questing away. Fun or frustrating? You decide.

Some missions are deliberately opaque, and require you to have unlocked a particular technology to complete the mission. The game does not tell you this, however, you just find out on your own once you’re down there. So you either abort and fail, or stay down and grind until you unlock the thing you need to win. Or you can read a Wiki and get instructions before you launch.

On that note, the world map is fixed. Most of the items always spawn in the same place, and once you know where caves are (for example), you know where to look. But the game does not mark things on your map for you, nor does it let YOU mark things on your map, other than placing a single target waypoint. (My heuristic is anything I can do with a paper and pencil, the game should be doing for me, so give me a persistent map I can mark up, guys!)

The “metagame” progression of unlocking items at the base also feels unnecessarily difficult and expensive. You have to “research” items for one cost, then “buy” them after researching them for another cost. The majority of these items seem to be only slightly better than the 2nd tier (of 4 tiers) items you can craft, and you can generally get to that level of crafting after a few minutes on each run.

The missions seem to fall into a few standard types: Gather materials, go scan at a location, kill some critters, or build a base.

Some of these missions are unnecessarily tedious, like requiring you to build a tower 10 stories high, and having to do it in a particular way so it doesn’t collapse under its own weight (which you can either figure out, or go look up on the internet). Perhaps the designers thought this would be a clever and fun puzzle. Maybe. But then you have to do it twice, exactly the same way. There was another one that required me to set up two different farms at opposite ends of the map, and run back and forth between them waiting for things to grow. 

There’s a lot of narrative inconsistency. You have a space suit, you have to fill it with oxygen, the atmosphere isn’t breathable…but you can get pneumonia in caves. You can’t bring stuff down with you, until you can bring some stuff down with you. You can’t bring stuff back, except for the stuff you have to bring back. You have a space suit, but no flashlight. And so on.

The game does a few things well, though. Icarus feels like it was balanced for multiplayer, and accommodates single-player by having a whole separate “Solo Skills” tree you can unlock, providing boosts for single-player runs only. That’s a clever solution, even if Icarus still feels excessively difficult solo.

The world looks decent, with lots of detail. There’s plenty of stuff to build. The biomes each present unique challenges, even if the weather is punishing no matter where you are.

I haven’t played multiplayer yet, but it seems like the game could really shine here.

Some of Icarus’ problems are fixable with some balancing and quality of life improvements. Beyond that, the devs added game modes so you can have your open-world sandbox or a lightweight "permanent" world without missions, and a paid DLC with what sounds like a proper campaign.

The base game is hard to recommend as it is, and yet there is something compelling about it. Still, it is ultimately a frustrating experience more than a relaxing or challenging one.

154954574.review:
The game itself is actually quite decent. I'd even suggest picking it up during a sale and giving it a try. However, what really stands out in this situation is the fanservice and the way the developers handle their promises and criticisms.

Lately, on their official Discord, it seems like all they do is talk about the expenses they're dealing with to make everything happen. Frankly, it gets a bit tiresome hearing about these complaints. They only seem to be active when they're about to release something new, like New Frontiers now. Other than that, they can go for months without any communication. They're going on about how much effort and money goes into creating a pet in the game, costing anywhere from $30k to $50k, and how players don't really understand the work behind it. Then they talk about features like full mod support, which we all know breathe life into games (remember how DayZ did it?), and they claim it would cost millions. They also mention something as simple as character customization being worth a million dollars.

"Rocket | CEO" mentioned that those who bought the Supporters Edition will eventually get a significant discount. Depending on how many units are sold, the Supporters Edition might even end up not costing the developers anything, or possibly even causing them to lose money, especially in certain regions.

Honestly, this kind of messaging to the people who believed in them and invested more to receive what was promised is a bit surprising. It's common knowledge that pre-orders and early supporters often get better deals. It's not rocket science (no pun intended). It seems like they're trying to make it look like they're the ones carrying the financial burden, which doesn't really sit right. This is a standard practice, and usually, it's the other way around – pre-orders are given at a discount.

I can already imagine the defenders who will argue that we should support the developers. It's fine to have differing opinions, but we need to be honest about our concerns.

The financial equation here is quite simple. The Icarus Deluxe Edition (that was the name of the edition I bought) costs $109.98, yet Styx, which everyone owning the game received for free, has a standalone cost of $23.44 (on promotion). The first DLC, priced at $25.49, brings the total to $48.93. Even if we factor in the $8.99 for Styx and a $5.99 add-on with lamps (which is also part of the deluxe edition), the total comes to $63.91 - and the next DLC won't cost $40 for sure, does that mean they'll start slicing out every little feature and selling them for $3-4 each just to hit that price point?

The lack of transparency in their communication is baffling. Any expression of dissatisfaction is met with backlash from their supporters, who don't seem to grasp that if you don't voice your concerns, you won't see any improvements. On Discord, you're flooded with messages about how everything is perfect and fantastic, which doesn't make sense for a game that's still in development (and it's supposed to be the first year in Early Access, but that's a whole other issue).

Encountering yet another update that introduces redundant features like two shields, coupled with the ongoing lack of progress in the development of the station shop and the repeatedly emphasized but elusive focus on future improvements, has thoroughly exhausted my patience. The absence of effective communication on these matters has significantly eroded my enthusiasm. I'm left in a state of uncertainty regarding the specifics of what the next game update will bring: what content will be added and how the game will evolve. The broad statements provided often fail to align with the actual changes that emerge when an update is eventually released.

Take a look at the sudden surge in positive reviews today – it's clearly orchestrated by them.

I'm sharing this negative feedback not because I dislike the game itself, but because I'm disappointed in the way the developers are handling their communication and game development. I'd still recommend buying and playing the game. While it's notably under-optimized, the recent changes seem to make the gameplay more accessible for a wider audience. Whether it suits your tastes or not is something you'll have to decide for yourself. If they follow through with the DLC as promised, it could potentially breathe new life into the game.

125075202.review:
I've been playing Icarus since its final 3 beta weekends. It's always a game I end up circling back to. I have played several different survival type games before (Ark, Rust, Terraria, Scum ect.) but nothing like this. Icarus is in a league of its own. CONSTANT updates keep the game fresh and interesting. Everything about the game revolves around its core concept, which unfortunately I feel most players miss. It's a SESSION BASED survival game. It plays more like a roguelike than a traditional survival game. Always under constant pressure of the mission clock, you have to get in, get your mission done and GET OUT. 10/10 devs NAIL IT when it comes to this game. You can play 1-8 players at a time, the game feels designed with group play in mind, but solo play is just as fun if more challenging. 

	As mentioned Icarus is a SESSION BASED survival game. This concept is the main point of negative reviews on this game. This is NOT a classic survival game. You have a mission that needs to be done and you need to leave. If you ever played ‘the Cycle: Frontier’ i like to think of icarus like that, you have a limited window of opportunity before the area becomes unlivable. Anything crafted or built is wiped after every session. A lot of players resent this as they spent time building bases, weapons, tools, getting tech upgrades and so fourth. In reality though, it is the core of the game. Part of your decisions involve figuring out how much you need to build to survive the mission at hand. Easy mission? Simple wood and bone tools/weapons can get you through no problem. Going into the more hazardous zones? “Tech up” to steel/platinum. 
	The game plays like a roguelike. Your missions reward you with research and sometimes exotics. Use these in the space station to buy upgrades from the workshop. A 3D printed knife won't last forever, but it will skip the need to make early items and speed up the early drop process. Advancing down the workshop tree IS the game's progression, not “in-mission” building. Only build what you NEED to survive.
	It is a survival game. You will need to find oxygen, food, and water to survive. As well as the harsh weather systems of the planet itself. Falling can kill you, fish can kill you, cave worms can kill you, starving can kill you, the harsh exposure CAN AND WILL KILL YOU. animals can be aggressive or passive, and some will attack when provoked. Icarus is not a safe place to be, and the game reminds you of that constantly. 
	You can tailor each drop to your preferred level of difficulty. Each mission will have a general rating scale from 1-4 ‘skulls’. You can make them easier for less rewards, or harder for more rewards. You can even insure your prospector for full safety, or go in HARDCORE for a true survival experience. There is permanent death for characters left behind.

	Combat is relatively simple, but has a few layers. There's stealth mechanics with sneak attack damage bonus. Crit mechanics. headshot/weak points (bonus damage). As well as hardpoints (less damage). All tools made also double as weapons in a pinch. Your pickaxe or regular ax won't do as much melee damage as quickly as a well crafted knife, but can save you in a pinch. Ranged weapons seem to be the go-to as it allows you to easily sneak and down hostile animals from safe distances.

	Icarus is absolutely BEAUTIFUL. Catch a sunrise as it bathes light into a forested valley and take a moment to appreciate the sights. I've played at minimum settings as well as EPIC settings and I have to suggest the highest your computer can handle.

Character progression
	There are 3 different progression systems in Icarus. Talent points, Blueprint points and the Workshop.
	Talent points: there are two major talent systems. Regular talent points and solo talent points. Every level up to level 50 rewards a standard talent point to spend. Every OTHER level also rewards a solo tree talent point. The SOLO tree is only active if you are on a mission by yourself. If someone joins your prospect, these talents go dormant. Each of your 50 talents can be spent to improve your character's specialization. Gathering, combat, building, survival. Whatever you want to focus on, there's a talent tree for it. Some crafting materials require certain talents so it's an excellent idea to browse and plan your talents as they are limited.
	Blueprints: These are more linear and will allow you to craft more complex items. Blueprint points will  continue to accrue even after max level 50. Which means if you play a character enough, you can eventually have everything in the blueprint trees. It's a good idea to always be sitting on about 5 blueprint points in case your mission calls for something you don't have already. 
	Workshop: The real progression system of icarus. Workshop items are your major upgrades. Each item helps you skip parts of the early game systems. Tired of making a stone pickaxe on drop? Buy one from the workshop and you can have it with you every mission (as long as you don't accidentally leave it behind OOPS). Workshop items require a steep initial research cost, but much smaller crafting cost, and they can be crafted multiple times if needed. Any workshop item you bring back will be renewed/repaired and available again for your next drop. This progression starts slow but ramps up as you get to the meatier missions. The best ones will cost you your valuable and difficult to obtain exotics, but it's well worth the price. Items include: tools, weapons, armor, suits, special ammunition, modules, and more. Each item has a way to make missions quicker by cutting out a part of on planet resource needs. The first tool/weapon in each branch is ROUGHLY equivalent to iron crafted gear, although crafted items during a drop will be slightly better, you can usually skip to the higher tier items as the Workshop items will last you until you have gathered/built up to them. Further down the tool and weapon trees are more specialized, and are steel or better quality items. These are ENTIRELY worth the hefty entry cost.

	Icarus punches back. Usually missions start off with light rain or light wind storms and progressively get more intense as the mission goes on. The weather updates on your HUD, yellow -> Red -> Black.  Be wary, a quick built wooden shelter will prevent you from taking exposure damage, but wont itself survive very long. Lightning can set entire forests ablaze, and wind can rip down trees. Exposure to the elements will slow you down, reduce your stamina and eventually start damaging you directly. The Icarus storms will kill.

Beginner tips
1. Early missions teach you how to survive and build within icarus’ systems. Use these early missions to get easy levels while the game isn't actively trying to kill you.
2. WORKSHOP ITEMS: MXC-knife, Water canteen, Oxygen tank. These 3 items save you the most time on drop for the cheapest entry cost. Get them.
3. You can stuff oxite (blue rocks) directly into the oxygen slot of your suit. Its not very efficient but will keep you alive

I cannot express enough gratitude to the AMAZING dev team behind this project. From the “refund no questions asked” beta, to the fulfilled promise of weekly updates. ACTUAL weekly updates. This has been something I find missing in 99% of games on the market. Icarus is easily a 60$–70$ game in size, scope, and dev support. They charge HALF that. Even the first large DLC was extra content, at no extra cost. This is INCREDIBLY rare in today's market. Kudos to them.

After playing Icarus for over 200 hours I estimate I've completed around 60-70% of the game. Roughly based on my workshop/blueprint progression and the number of unique missions completed. Cant wait to see whats next.

“We were like cave people in spacesuits those first few drops….The second you felt comfortable on the surface, you take your eye off the mission clock, and that's how people died” -Sol (Icarus: No Rescue)

114257160.review:
so obviously i've played this a LOT, i can't say i didn't get my monies worth after keeping me busy this long .. however ..

There are still some pretty heavy issues with the game, the number of updates is impressive and they are always implementing new things but issues still remain that have been there since the beta.

The static map, although touted as a better option over a procedurally generated one, has some major drawbacks.  One of them being that the map is always the same .. its good in that if you know here the caves are now you always will but the bad part is that eventually nothing is new anymore.  You effectively play the same map over and over and over as you're always starting again from scratch and this can make you feel like you've played the game to DEATH.

Map issues are also prevalent such as walls that aren't there, resources you cant get to because of an invisible wall, resources appearing inside rock, mission items that only show up for the host, burnt trees that cause players to fall through the map or cause players sessions to reload the ui (and usually end up with you falling through the map over and over).

Part of the draw of the game originally was the premise in that you did missions to open up items for research and purchase to aid you in the next missions, there is an element of truth in that however let me be clear, once you played for a little while and got the few items that actually help you in game .. forget about anything else.  Outside of them armour and one or two tools there becomes no reason to need cash or exotics and therefore no more reason to really want to do any more missions.

For me the only real draw anymore has become the building aspect, in that the game also falls short.  the graphics are beautiful up to a point, there are a number of build materials however with recent changes its only worth going up to stone, the changes to the cement mixer now means it takes eons to get a decent amount to build in concrete.  The build pieces above stone are severely limited in terms of what you can place.  Wood and stone can have double wide windows, anything higher than that is only single windows .. that kind of thing.

Above that the build engine itself is very limited, if you want to only ever build in 90 degree angles .. you're in luck, otherwise give up now.  Before this i played Valheim and the difference in the build system outside of the graphics is huge.

Don't get me wrong they have added in certain things such as being able to build half walls instead of full and less steep roofs however the build pieces they put in are cosmetic only.  Want to build on top of that half wall ? .. nope cause it still sees it as a full wall, want to build a less steep roof but keep the same width of building ? .. nope .. cause the less steep roof is designed to be used with another piece making it the original height but twice as wide, if you try building using just one piece it doesn't connect.  You also can't place anything that is less than a full tile, if you want to have say a balcony well its going to be a full floor.  Yes you could use a half piece to add a balcony but forget about putting railings on the side cause theres no half railing or half tile walls. 

Now as i said originally don't get me wrong, i've got my monies worth out of the game but as it stands now .. there is just no draw to play.  Missions are boring and repetitive, starting from scratch every map is a pain (yes i know it said that at launch but once you've played 2000 hours you lose interest), building system is limited and uninspiring .. you will never see the type of innovation such as other games (Valheim).

If you didn't buy the supporters edition you can also forget about more than one type of biome for outposts, this means if you do want to just build to your hearts content, you're going to be very bored in you're choice of location.  you get a 4 sector radius to build in and thats it, no predators or heavy storms which is a good thing on the surface but a bad thing in that its hard to hunt effectively for food or leather.  resources respawn whenever you load in which is nice but considering the limited building that outpost wont keep you interested long.

Now after all this someone is going to say Hey .. its only been out 6 months and that's true however silly little things like expanding all building options to all materials, so you can have an extra wide window in concrete for instance, should NOT be that hard to implement and its been requested on the suggestions forum time and time again.  I guess in the end this is just a survival game with a little bit of building in it.

Yes i still have to recommend it cause after 2000 hours how can i not but I don't see it lasting much longer for me.

Intentions: I came to play a solo game that was aesthetically pleasing with a dynamic environment as promised by the 'failed terraforming' processes that have occurred. Where are the adaptable creatures that aren’t mindlessly walking around ignoring each other?

The whole Tier 4 needs a re-work and rebalance. Nothing makes sense and the only figures Rocketwerkz has made sure is right are the stamina and walk-speed. They really don’t want you getting to the end and finding out the mission was actually pointless but hey, why not add running all the way back to the dropship for the hell of it, yay! This is usually where I realise I am hoarding lackluster consumables (ie grenades) for no reason and spend about 200 bullets on the way out shooting everything and anything including pumpkins, beyond survival, just a slaughter back to the dropship thinking to myself 'that was kinda lame'.....then 'Storm Incoming' pops up....Get me out. 
 
Sadly disappointed as this was what I have been looking forward to playing over the holidays and now I am back to the drawing board of options. I hope in time it will progress from the unofficial ‘Early Access Game’ it is now to an unofficial Full Version 1.0.

The business idea:

Make a space survival game with missions, to shine from other survival games.
Go buy pre-built blocks of content and glue it together as a game.

105206470.developer_response:
I'd like to reassure you that this is not our business model and we're here to keep growing and investing in Icarus. We've published five hotfixes in the first week and new content for the second weekend.

>>Make a space survival game with missions, to shine from other survival games.
Yes! This is Icarus' point of difference. Rather than long sprawling open-world wandering we tried to focus it into sessions. 

>>Sell 1 million copies, and go home.
We haven't gone anywhere. We're busy updating and adding to the game. 

The session-based structure means we can add new modes, missions and content to the game without unbalancing your existing progress. For example, this weekend we're adding a new mission that unlocks an entire new player ability (not just another talent or craftable item). 

>> Just get the earth stuff and make it "alien", maybe a mammoth as they are not on earth anymore.
Yes, Icarus is an Earth-like terraformed planet and all our advertising, trailers and streams showed that. It's also by design. We reckon that to build tension and immersion a survival game should start of familiar and be relatable. If it was purple fantasy alien monsters it might be a different genre of game. The sci-fi setting provides the flexibility for us to add new tech - and creatures


>>Ok, space is about biomes, so we make biomes from ice, desert and forest. Close enough.
Star Wars episodes V, IV and VI. 

>>No real content? Just make it grindy and drag it past the 2 hours refund period before it is revealed.
As you buy items from the orbital Workshop you start each mission with a head-start - a faster or better axe, new equipment. You character will already have unlocked a bunch of talents and items to progress faster, and have new ways to play the game. 

As for content, there are two tech trees, one with four tiers of  230+ craftable items, over 240+ talents, a 64km square map at launch, over 40 missions and more being added.  

We have a team of 60+ people working on Icarus and our business plan is to make an awesome survival game with a strong player community for years to come.

Player: - So you can level up yourself and recieving talent points right?

P: You mentioned in game description the "savage alien wilderness", so there is a many different creature and exciting fight and combat techniques?
D: Not at all ofc! There is only a wolves, wildboar and bear in forest bioms,  wolves, snow leopard and polar bear in arctic bioms.... And to mix up things,  we put cougar to desert biom, along with hiena, boar and elefant. We know the cougar lives in the mountains, but WHO CARE? :D Isn't it?

108182831.review:
Updated review 2.25.22! 
My original review was not to recommend this game based on numerous issues with both the functionality of the game and the QoL of the player, as well as what felt like missing content. There are also much needed changes to really make this game a more well-rounded, immersive experience, but that being said, here are my original recommendations and what has been changed so far, and why I changed my review to recommend this game!
Original Recommended fixes and what's been done: 
1) I don't think the farming/grinding needs to decrease, as that's part of the fun (if there's a reason for it). The time spent actually completing an objective once you're done with farming and grinding should increase to make all of it actually worth it. - This has been a constant review and update process for the developers, and so far it's been going in the right direction, although not resolved yet. With their commitment that they're still reviewing this aspect, paired with what they've updated so far, I'm comfortable waiting to see how this pans out!
2)Work on bugs instead of releasing more repetitive prospects. - This started happening! So many bug fixes so far! Yes, there are still quite a few, but they don't feel so immersion-breaking or game crashing.
3)Implement the quality of life changes that were recommended in the beta weekends that don't impact the gameplay or difficulty. - HUGE improvements in this area in the Week 11 and Week 12 content. This has really made the game all around MUCH more enjoyable, including some of the previous aspects that were considered to be very tedious.
4) Make the tech tree items more relevant, and reduce the cost of higher tier items. - The developers have committed to improving this as well, so also looking forward to these updates! The minor changes to the cost of higher tier items helped, but they're still not viable or feasible for like 90%+ of the missions. 
5) Add talent points to use in the solo branch, independent of the regular branch. - This was done in the week 12 update!
6) Give the animals more AI. Add more flora and fauna diversity. - Still waiting on this as well. There were some minor improvements made here where animals will now react to sounds differently and don't get stuck on a rock or tree, and they no longer hear or see through stone walls of your shelter (unless they're right next to you outside), but I consider this as still in progress...
7) Add more lore! - Still waiting patiently for this!
