149695242.review:
So I stopped playing this game around week 40ish, mostly due to stability issues. (30 or less fps with a 3070 and even worse during weather events and also while hosting) however I decided to come back and see how much the game has improved and I'm Incredibly pleased to see me getting 144+ fps with the same setup I had back then but with a much better resolution to boot. optimization has improved immensely and I'm glad they actually put effort into doing so. the newly added updates every week between now and then has made the game far more enjoyable and fun for me as well with the game itself being a nice mix of chill relaxing moments and tense sudden ones.

The good: There Is a lot that Icarus brings to the table

Base building is very aesthetically pleasing, especially once you get to stone and refined wood structures, bases begin to look so comfortable and nice looking. a lot of this game is nice to look at, with lush forests, harsh deserts and oasis and barren tundras.

Crafting and progressing is a chore sometimes depending on where you are, but feels rewarding at least to me. I've always found it nice to finally get away from early game tools and weapons and then upgrade to steel or higher, being able to bring items from the workshop also aids in early advancement and is nice because workshop items aren't OP but they are far better than stone and some iron.

The world of Icarus feels brutal as everything feels against you, animals both familiar and unfamiliar are always out to get you, and the weather events are there to level everything you've built with only the toughest of bases brushing off these storms. Lightning storms will rage and cause fires that consume anything burnable nearby unless countered, strong winds can level wooden bases before you realize It, sandstorms can burn you out of your home and snowstorms can quite literally crush your base.

Audio Isn't too bad either, animals, player actions and overall noises are great (axe and pickaxe sounds could be lowered a bit) The storms also sound amazing with the game having some of the most Intense sounding weather In nearly any game I've played. 

The bad: The game Isn't all sunshine and rainbows, there are still quite a few issues that need addressing.

Combat Isn't entirely bad but with the game having "bosses" that can really ruin your day they need to be made to feel like bosses instead of just stronger variants of an animal. Having attacks that you could telegraph and dodge to avoid damage Is needed heavily instead of every encounter having said creature just rushing you and attacking non stop, this isn't combat its a damage check at that point between you and the enemy.

Spawning Is also a bit of an issue, especially in the desert with random cougars and scorpions just poofing into existence right in front of you and Immediately aggroing you is just bad spawn design, spawns need to be set out of player sights and a distance away so they can perceive the threat and act accordingly on whether to fight or run.

AI isn't terrible but I don't believe all carnivores should immediately be out to kill you, bears are a good example of this, being territorial is one thing but watching a bear traverse a mountain just to come near my base, see me in my window and start breaking my walls to get to me is a bit much. there should be warning calls or ways for animals to basically say "back off" and warn the player. Herbivores shouldn't also turn tail and run when the spot you a mile away, they should just notice you're there and keep an eye on you, If you start acting like you're about to attack them or move towards them then yes, run for the hills.

Last but not least the UI needs an overhaul, I hate having to open every fireplace or furnace and physically click a button to turn on, or having to click a button to craft, there should just be a hot key for that. as for the HUD, I feel that needs a rework as well. While It isn't horrid to look at, it feels very bulky in terms of screen space, theres so much unnecessary info being displayed at all times and at times i just end up playing with the HUD turned off.

Overall Icarus Is by no means a bad game, sure It isn't for everyone. but if you enjoy a game that can bring both a challenge and be relaxing at the same time then It may be for you. The devs release new updates nearly every week, they listen quite a lot to community suggestions and are actively working to fix issues that players find. The game from this point will only get better.

129227340.review:
Edit 28th April 2023: After several performance updates the game is now much better to play in terms of performance. We can now enjoy it the way it was meant to be!

An awesome game with huge potential plagued by huge optimisation issues. This game is somewhat a tricky one which the devs really need to take some time to fix the serious issues within the engine. 
I had been following the development of this game for a while before it's main release last year but after being put off from it's initial release just over a year ago due to the lack of a continuous open world mode and the thought of having to start from scratch every time, they finally released and open world mode which was enough for me to give it a shot.

Upon loading into an Open world mode map, at epic detail on my 5800x RTX 3080 32GB RAM system I am greeted with 110-140 fps in a truly beautiful looking world. The tech trees and talent trees can be a little overwhelming at first but pretty easy to understand and navigate once you get to grips with things. 
Farming for resources is very satisfying especially trees, they've really done well with the eye candy and sounds in this game but quite honestly that's where the good stuff ends. 
The AI is poor and very repetitive and not very realistic and somewhere along my 80 hours of play, the game has just turned into a choppy lag fest rarely getting over 45 FPS. I ran many tests while also running through several guides online to try and gain back my FPS but without success. Initially I though it might have been my base causing the FPS drop so i made a stone 3x2 nearby and put everything into cupboards inside and deconstructed my main base in the hope that FPS was restored. Unfortunately I was to be disappointed as I was getting the exact same choppy 41-45 FPS as before. 
If I load a new prospect and drop in I get the perfect 110-140 FPS again but it does definitely seem that something, somewhere is causing the game to slow down.
Two of my friends also started playing at the same time I did, one of which has an almost identical system to me and they're both experiencing the same stuff. One of them has an AMD card and, well the lag is much worse especially when a fire lit entity is active. 

All in all if you play the missions mode where you drop in to a fresh world each time I think these issues are non existent but open world definitely needs some severe work to get it playable. I understand it's a new mode and is going to need some tweaking, I just hope that the devs honestly DO take the time to sort this out.

Rocket Werkz, if you get these things ironed out then this game will be up there as one of the best survival games ever made, but for now it's just going to fade into the background. The average monthly players is hovering around 2-2.5k but if you get this optimisation fixed then that will for sure go up. 
Less focus on adding more in game items please and get this fixed as for now, this game will just sit in my library until i see an update where they specifically say they have made some optimisation fixes. 

Oh and devs, please dont respond with a generic message asking me to try the latest drivers. I am up to date with everything possible.

124175566.review:
A game that started with enormous potential, but has since been crippled by development schizophrenia in the worst possible way. Every decision they make undermines another, every addition renders something else pointless or betrays the vision originally presented back in beta. 

The game is riddled with competing concepts that lack even the most basic logical grounding - exemplified by the spacesuit you're forced to wear that needs continual top-up with mineralised oxygen while the deer and bears breathe freely, and that is simultaneously airtight enough to last indefinitely underwater while charged yet porous enough to risk pneumonia after less than a minute of exposure to cave air.

I edited this review because I initially said it was worthless, and that was unfair. Some very talented people have worked on Icarus. But until and unless the core conceptual dissonance is addressed - and there is absolutely no sign of that happening, even now - Icarus will always be a great idea that failed.

130330625.review:
Well, after 44 hours of apparently playing the wrong mode, I've come to the conclusion that this is a good game.

So, to be clear, I didn't start with the missions. I expected I'd hate them, and as such, I started with the open world. It then proceeded to be one of the most entertaining things I'd done in some time. I intended for this to be something to play in the background while I played other games, and talked with friends, but no, this game consumed me for 3 days straight. I bought this game on Wednesday, it's now Saturday at the time of this review. I have done nothing but play this game, only begrudgingly sleeping when the beautiful storm sounds started to put me to sleep.

I love so much about this game, and I never even left the forest region. I adore games with a level of freeform progression, the style that doesn't force you down an inevitable path, but rather offers you a choice of how you'd like to build your own progression path. I love the building, and the farm required for it. I love the hunting, how it feels to stealth kill your first bear. I love sitting in my stone house, watching the rain fall outside during the absolutely amazing storms that come and go.

I could gush about this game for hours, but I'll stop myself before I go any further. There is, unfortunately, a downside that caused me to lose all my drive for the game.

As I mentioned at the start, it turns out that the open world isn't really intended for you to dump all your time into. The intended gameplay is within missions, and after playing the opening one, I gotta say, I'm glad I started on the open world.

Being dumped into that world as I was had so much mystery and wonder, trying to work out through text clues why this was an alien world with Earth's animals and environments. Having some dude just explain everything to you really does break the wonder and mystery behind the universe. I had infinitely more fun floundering my way through a forest with nothing but a stone pick in one hand, and my hopes and dreams in the other.

Had I opened with those missions, I'd have given up long, long before I did. If you enjoy these kinds of games, and enjoy learning without a tutorial, skip the missions and play the open world. It's a far more satisfying experience. 

The problem that killed it for me was the apparent lack of Exotics, the end game currency, and the entire reason you're there. From what I've read and experienced, Exotics can only be obtained from missions, which was such an utter and unbelievable disappointment for me that I simply gave up. I'd reached composite armour, with full tier 4 gear, and was level 40 by the time I quit. I was prepping myself for some incredible end game boss or activity, but none came. The bosses I read about in the medals screen turned out to be nothing but sidequests.

So, yes, I do recommend it, but I have some serious hangups with the design as a whole. I can only recommend it based on the sheer amount of fun I had playing that one open world map, as the missions really did it in for me. While I likely won't come back to the game, I do appreciate the days of missing my friend's messages because I was too engrossed in building pointy sticks to keep the big bad wolves out of my stone huts.

106218105.review:
Hi, Iam Ken the guy who makes the bear videos. The first question I have to ask you is, Do you love yourself?
Before you answer that question read this review about this game. I have played this game for hours solo to the point of burning out my soul.

You start off on planet Icarus, a terraformed planet gone wrong, It might seem like earth, it might feel like earth, but you can't breathe it's air, You'll maybe see two creatures in this game that will not be earthlike but the rest are either earth and maybe one from past earth to get you excited in the game but that's it, everything else is EARTH. The sci fi aspect of this game adds a mysterious zing to it of what you are trying to do on this planet as a prospector who works for a company the story is you basically are offered quest to drop on the planet and build everything from scratch EVERY MISSION every TIME because the planet is brutal and wipes everything else after a certain amount of hours or days.

So you got that cool base you build? Don't put value into anything that isn't brought down from the planet because if so, anything on built on the planet everytime you start a new mission so forget about sentimental values and attachments. You can only earn them to bring some down to the planet but whats the purpose? To basically help you farm more and more and farm more or kill better etc, gives a bit of help but overall not much.

At first the graphics are amazing, everything feels fresh and new and the game is a whoa factor for the first few hours, but after you start playing the quest you start to realize that the mission in this game is pretty pointless and uninspiring because you will prospect plants, you will build outpost, you will kill predators, but best of all you will go scout areas out across the same map over over, Go from point A, to B, to C, and then come back to your dinky ship and take off into space knowing that you did a great job for a company you don't know much about to be rewarded with hard earn money to buy items to help you farm more. 

The problem isn't the farming, but the mechanics of everything that will drive you apeshit up the walls, You got some light source like Torch/Lamps? in your hand? Gotta drop it so you can see in caves so you can mine, stay in cave too long? You get pneumonia in your space suit its brutal and sometimes these brutal aspects can be fun but at the same time begs you to question WHY Can't you hold a pickaxe in one hand while attach the light to your waist? and the pneumonia in the spacesuit getting that every cave will drive you insane, its a tough world.

The talent tree right now is super limited, its understandable how you can't learn everything but at the same time there isn't enough points so you have to build a certain way if you want to excel at something, I basically built a survival weight ore farmer which helps eases my ore farming but everything else was meh, Iam not good at combat so bears tear me apart or I use more materials than most to build my build and outwit the apex predators but at the same time I wish I could put more points in the tree to actually feel good that I built a certain way but I do not and I have created 3 characters level 40+ doing so.

Sure the blueprints are cool to glance at first and you realize OH you just have to go up the tree to get to tier 3 or tier 4 or so on but it isn't until you start doing the tier 4 and farm the amount of electronics, coppers, and Epoxy and so on that you really question your sanity, It took me 15 hours to get to tier 4 and exploring 20+ caves to find what I need to find, to make life easier you need to make a lantern, Copper is plentiful but amount needed along with gold makes it a drag when it comes to farming the material, 15+ hours to get what I needed to get to tier 4 just to find out I NEED EVEN MORE OF it for the quest but not only that limited by the time you will rush becuase if the timer reaches zero ROH OH your character is deleted. So do you want to spend time messing around on the planet with tier 4? NOPE NO REASON TO AFTER the quest

Along with all these you will be hit by bugs and bad optimization, The memory leaks right now are horrendous and because some of the bugs you will see it will drive you up the wall, literally walls that glitches out you can run into, invisible walls that stops you from visiting other parts of the maps, ORES that stick out of the ground only a quarter of the way so you can only get one hit and so on will make you want to Punch your monitor.

Sure people are praising the fact that they are adding new stuff everytime new missions weekly and so forth and hotfixes but does it address the balance issue of the game? Does it address the FUN FACTOR? The Quality of life needed?
Nope not as of yet. The missions added and being praised for is nothing new but the same 10+ missions you been doing already for every biome which is Forest, River, Desert and Snow, Nothing to keep you interested or care about your building on the planet at all, the lore is kinda cool that the planet is evolving at a fast pace but until it is seen probably in DLC you are better off waiting for Avatar if you want to see more aliens.

I have played many fun survival, farming, or even grinding games in my life, The forest, Atlas, Ark and so on thousands of hours and even though I sit around and wait to tame a dinosaur I know I had a purpose, this game makes me feel like I have none at all, no real purpose except to work for the company and make them money which is fine but the rewards aren't enough to make me feel satisfied. You might wonder with the amount of time I played on this game 133.7 which is hilarious and purely coincidence that I would recommend it, but I will not because of the sheer amount it takes for a solo player to farm to get to where they are is completely  tedious to the point I wanted to punch my pinky against a coke can sometimes.

105883112.review:
Let me start off by saying that this is the first game that has made me irate enough to actually write a review. And its really sad because I was really enjoying it. I absolutely loved the crafting and building. So much so that I got my character to level 20 within the first few hours of playing and then spent literally the next 25-30 hours playing in the outpost mode, building and crafting a permanent base. 

The problems with this game are not game play related. If you love survival games, you'll enjoy the game play. The problems with this game are much deeper. The problems start with the updates. Every other day there is a hot fix or patch being put into place. On its face this is good. However, don't think you'll just be able to download a 200 MB patch and you'll be ready to play, BECAUSE THAT'S NOT HOW IT WORKS. You download the 200 MB patch and then have to wait anywhere from 20 MINUTES TO 2 HOURS to actually play the game as is patches and reinstalls THE ENTIRE 48GB OF THE GAME. Hope you don't have much going on in your life because if you do, you probably won't have the time for this game. 

This now leads to the BIGGEST GAMEBREAKING BUG I have ever personally encountered. When I started the game, there were three outpast maps available to choose from. Arcwood (forest region), Holdfast (forest region), and Iceholm (snow region). I wanted to just build a forest outpost, chose Holdfast, and went to work. I built a full on castle outpost, just finished putting in a guard house last night. Come to log on this morning and boom. Another update. So I let it go while I'm working thinking I can hop on at lunch and complete the kitchens. I start the game, go to the outpost page, go to select Holdfast....EXCEPT ITS FREAKING LOCKED. Turns out, that only people who purchased the Supporters Edition of the game were supposed to have Holdfast and Iceholm as outpost options! The fact that I had them as options was a bug. I never buy the upgraded versions of games, always the just the base game. I never even look to see what the upgraded versions are offering because its usually just extra cosmetics or some crap like that. HOW WAS I SUPPOSED TO KNOW THAT I SHOULDN'T HAVE HAD ACCESS TO THE OUTPOST THAT I WAS SINKING ALL OF MY TIME INTO?! I NOW HAVE NO OUTPOST, NO PATIENCE, AND NO DESIRE TO CONTINUE PLAYING THIS GAME. I TRADED MY MONEY FOR A GAME THAT I COULD SINK MY TIME INTO AND THIS GAME TOOK MY MONEY AND ROBBED ME OF MY TIME!!

So they asked me the host to reload the save to fix the issues... when I tried to reload the prospect the client crashed... I tried a few more times and it would crash every time I attempted to load. I asked my friends to try and load the prospect, they all had the same crash when loading the prospect.

Not only was the prospect save corrupted, no one in my group could remove the prospect from their characters. So now our characters and their progress is useless and all us would need to start over again.

Maybe they will get their crap together in the future, but for now this game needs to fix some core issues before more play it.

149352268.review:
A group of my online buddies migrated to this game and I was hesitant to join them at first and I regret not getting into it sooner. I have been having a great time and I'm gonna keep playing it for at least a few dozen more hours and I'll honestly pick up the DLC and get even more out of it. I like "cozy" games and while this is not is free of challenge, its a very nice experience to play on normal after a long crappy day at work. You can get on for 20 minutes and do nothing and it feels good. You can play for six hours and go, "Wow, I really accomplished a lot!"

The Bad: It can be pretty grindy, resources are sort of finite. The tutorial is threadbare to say the least. I asked my friends questions on how to do things and even they were like, "I dunno man." That is also good though because there is just so much in the game. So either go in with a group of friends, be prepared for a lot of trial and error, or watch a few hours of YouTube videos that can be wildly out of date from a few months ago. The game is not free of bugs and some things are buggier than other (looking at you electric tool). The dedicated servers need help, badly. They have bugs that just don't exist in solo or peer-to-peer play. You will lose so many mounts by falling through the world. Hot tip, when you starting falling, hit F as soon as possible to dismount and it will save your life. There are too many storms and the storms are too punishing to be out in. I do not like the tech and talent tree system, I could write so much more on how they could be better. Make sure you think way ahead before you put points into something. I would recommend going deep into a single combat tree first and then picking another tree to go into. Guns are fun but resource intensive, bow and arrow is very reliable and steady, but after doing both of those for a while I ended up settling on javelins and knives. I use the hunting rifle and shotgun for the "oh shit" moments. Don't feel bad about editing your character or save. 

The good: This will run on a potato, yes you'll have to put the graphics to low but honestly it looks pretty good on low. I can play it on my very aged work gaming laptop. The game looks good but the graphics will need some tweaking for your set up. The building is simple but robust, it uses tiles and snapping which I really like. Some people don't like tile/snapping but there are enough bits and options that it really doesn't stifle creation. The combat is fun. It's very simple and basic, but in a way that is nice. You can just fight and you'll come across something that will just mess you up badly but you never feel like it was cheap, you feel like you learned something. The game and loop is engaging and fun. They give you a lot of things to manage but none of them feel unmanageable. It feels like a good "life simulator" but for a fun video game. You have to sleep and get up and drink water and prepare food and tend to your animals as the "work" part of the game but all that enables you to do the fun parts and the process of the work is fun too. Unless it storming, then you ain't doing shit outside. Honestly, there are so many good things about the game that I could ramble about it for hours. Don't think you need to play multiplayer, some of the most fun I've had is playing at 3:00 AM in my solo play. 

I could see why its overall score is mixed. I am not super familiar with the game at launch as I only started playing a few weeks ago. I think that, right now, this game is more than solid and I have no problem recommending it with the only caveat that you need to be willing to look things up and ask questions. It will not be hand-fed to you. The development team is incredibly active on their official Discord and answer questions and talk to the community about what's going to be added next. They do a patch every week which is just crazy and I respect it. Also no microtransactions! You buy the DLC if you like it and want more, perfect business model! If you enjoy what I like to call "stick-and-rock-games" you're going to like this. It's not as punishing as Rust, it's not as kiddy as Minecraft, its not as cartooney as Valheim, it's the right blend of all of them.

EDIT: A few weeks have gone by since I have posted this review. They have actually addressed most of the things I gripe about. Resources respawn to a certain extent and there are additional ways to get things. I still think the EXP progression and minimal amount of points you get compared to amount trees/skills is skewed poorly. You grind a ton for levels and barely have enough points. I still say: If you don't have a concrete plan going into a character, just edit it.

111221638.review:
A game with this many updates deserves recognition. They add new features and fix issue on a weekly basis, every complaint I had against this game has been fixed or revised. The open worlds have method to earn rewards and perform missions, and the base portion of the game is much more fleshed out. Reaching the high tiers in the crafting tree is rewarding and not nearly as tedious as it once was. Although the map is still spaced out, the mounts are significantly faster than when they first came out, and the Moas make traveling round the map a breeze

Previous Review: Mechanics are fun at first, but you quickly realize all the missions are walking simulators. You spawn in across the map from the location you have to perform actions at, run there, place the item you were given for the mission, wait 5 mins, run back.  The combat is stale, all the animals have nearly identical AIs, and killing them is not difficult.

Edit for Week 46:
Moa mount is cool, and is fast, but dies so quickly its almost not worth it. In the long run a speed oriented build makes the player faster on foot. Combat still sucks, on the harder difficulties the levels attempt to overwhelm the player with sheer numbers, having to fight multiple polar bears at once. Usually the easiest solution is to build a platform and kill from there. 

Ill be back again, but I hope they add an open world survival that includes the ability to complete multiple missions at once. That might make the grind for the fourth tier worth it.

117991306.review:
There's a lot of ambition in this game, but the truth is, it's an unfinished Early Access game being sold as a final product. There's just so much that clearly isn't finished by the devs. A brief list:

- No online matchmaking. There's a "quick play" button that's literally just greyed out and does nothing. 
- You can only play with trusted steam friends, because there's zero anti-griefing mechanics or design implemented yet.
- Game chugs and struggles on the default settings, frequent stutters and gpu lag. Really unoptimized. 
- Purchased off the shelf art assets
- Lots of missions with balance or goal issues, like grinding for 20 hours to get hundreds of meat 1 at a time.
- They are still finishing major, core features of the game. Weekly updates might totally change how core gameplay mechanics work ... because the game isn't finished!
- Game will frequently crash with "out of video" memory
- Backend servers recently had a 5+ hour outage, where no one could save, pause, or quit their game without losing all their progress.

If you're fine paying $35 for an EA game that's might randomly crash and wipe your progress, or be different week to week, then sure. But they should be honest about the state of the product, and they aren't.

This game is more frustration than fun.  Maybe later it will be worth the time.  At least it's cheap.
